Reviews: So dumb, bad acting, predictable, dumb... Like really dumb.

It is an obvious Seven Samurai Sci Fi ripoff. Seven Samurai is an be if my all time favorites,  and this movie does it justice. The visual effects are outstanding and the creatures are some of the best ever. I am very pleased that I turned this on.

Characters are too dull,too many unnecessary scenes that tried to look cool. No chemistry among the "rebels". With all the scifi movies and series being released recently, this one seems outdated in terms of themes and direction. 10 year old kids would love this though.

Visually it's a very impressive film. Lots of great sci-fi action sequences and the slow-mo fight scenes are pretty fun to watch. However, the overall story feels pretty generic and bland. The main characters literally just go on a fetch-quest for bunch of people that they've heard of who can help them on their journey, watch as they demonstrate some kind of badass ability or fight, and then they join the group. That's pretty much it up to the end fight against the main villain which was also pretty underwhelming. While it has its fun moments, overall it falls pretty flat. Let's hope part 2 coming up soon expands the story and makes up for the lack of substance in part 1.

This movie was great.  Not perfect but great.  Funny, expansive, world building, familiar but not a duplicate.  It was FUN...remember when movies were sometimes just entertaining and FUN? I knew nothing about this movie before I stumbled on it. Wow! Love the story, love the perfectly cast characters. It is a great action adventure movie. Not long before I hit pause to Google who the director is. No surprise. I've watched it twice and will watch it again.

Rebel moon has rich visual storytelling. The opening scene with the narrative of an empirical world who destroyed their planet and the tragedy that forced the loss of their Monarchy, teasing treachery, and political intrigue and strife while introducing an indomitably cruel and sadistic minor antagonist who is but a pawn for the final Villain antagonist directing things from the shadows is an ominous launching point for the story.  

The protragonist, Kora, later to be revealed to be a girl in hiding by another name has an intricately complicated relationship with the final Villain antagonist which only strengthens the plot surrounding her journey to gather individuals to her cause that could defeat this indomitable foe.

Her journey however, begins on a planet as a simple farmer, but we soon learn what she is and her intricate background soon reveals itself in narrative and action as well as her knowledge of how to deal with the newcomers to the planet Veldt, which to the imminent peril of the inhabitants of Veldt is largely ignored. 

The history of the story at times is spoken in narratives to move the story along, but this seems to be due to the time limits placed on the story, which sits roughly at 2 hours and 16 minutes. It could have been an 8 hour show, filling with  expansive descriptive storytelling about the people, the universe and the cultures.

The actual narratives accompanied by flashbacks are rich with historical significance and recognizable symbolism, and has all the action packed nuance of previous Zack Snyder works with well choreographed fight scenes that move the story in references to previous scenes, and expansion of the influence of powers in the universe. These action scenes also offer supplemental knowledge to the dialogue revealing strengths, weaknesses and experience of characters that help you understand who they are, where they came from and why they are there. 

This first installment is an incredible introduction into a rich and vibrant universe that has the potential to become more than just the story that's told, and I look forward to future installments that continue to create a more vibrant painting of a universe, it's politics and it's people who live within it.

With incredible performances by Sofia Boutella (Star Trek: Beyond, The Kingsman: the Secret Service) , Djimon Hounsou (Gladiator, Guardians of the Galaxy, A Quiet Place  part II), Ray Fisher (Justice League, The piano Lesson) , Anthony Hopkins (The Silence of the Lambs, The Father, One Life, The Mask of Zorro) and many more.

When they walked into a bar full of weird aliens and then immediately picked a fight, I told my wife that if they walked out with a guy who had a spaceship to take them to the next place then we were turning it off.  So.  I don't know what actually happened because I had to be true to my word.

It's like it was supposed to be a short series, with back stories and subplots, but instead we just get little episodes of characters that have meaningless background.

Cool action scenes but a bit over choreographed.

Setting changes were jarring and haphazard.

And the final scene was completely unnecessary.

Yes, the dialogue is cheesy. Yes, we've seen all the tropes portrayed in this movie before. Yes, the slo-mo was gratuitous. However, the story itself was relatively original, most shots were beautiful, and there's enough familiarity for any sci-fi/fantasy fan to just lock in and be entertained for a few hours. It may not be groundbreaking but it's still a good time and worth a watch if you enjoy the genre. Don't expect to be blown away by any twists or completely original ideas. Instead, enjoy it for what it is: a fun movie with some original creature designs and a classic good vs. space Nazis plot.

As the beginning of a story, Rebel Moon hits all the marks it aims to. It's a film that wears its influences on its sleeve and still manages to provide a few surprises along the way. In particular, the film's handling of major themes like colonialism and empire are top-notch, providing a grounding realism to what could have been simply a flashy space adventure.
The first hour felt interesting enough.  The second hour felt generic, and ultimately not very satisfying/compelling.

it tries to create this big world, but gets rushed and ends up to be flat.
In summary, it's a chain of quick quests to get new companions so you can fight the final boss.

There's a lot of potential in Rebel Moon's universe, but the haphazardly handled mess of a story proves to be a dumb ride from planet to planet in search for a team to fight a battle that never takes place in this movie anyway

Completely lacking in originality and personality, but entertaining enough sci-fi action and drama with a dark and serious setting. Hopefully the next film will add some depth to the characters and explore the interesting seeds such as the robot's humanity.

This movie lacks in early character development but doesn't disappoint with a healthy supply of action and plot events.  I think it is easy to dock the movie for the early lack of plot, but it also must be remembered that this is part 1 and if part 2 delivers the same amount of action and build upon the lackluster story, It might blossom into what most of us would consider a terrific sci fi film.

Gritty. Stunning. Builds a universe on the genius of Star wars, dune, bladerunner et al.  I cannot disagree with the critics on the concepts 'stolen' but does this movie not combine the best of elements of the above.  Epic landscapes, worlds dedicated to mining, human nature at is worst... greed and power, and best....  Where it is unique is in not introducing Jedi force magic like Star wars, therein lies the fantasy of childhood dreams. 
However, we do have several 'magnificent samurai' , who although they do not use magic are so incredibly talented that we are being led to believe that they alone can take a stand against a hugely powerful controlling empire like governance.  The magnificent seven, the samurai too were outnumbered but not outgunned.  In this first movie the inspirational characters needed more development, they needed to perhaps survive an attack and realize that they needed to split up and rally their own factions over time.  The village is merely symbolic here, it's about the struggle against a cruel oppressive rule, a fight for peace through autonomy, a drive for fairness and respect, in that respect it is, or should not be, the seven samurai. Sadly the closing scenes are the seven back on the original planet, perhaps the second movie will see people and weapons flocking to the planet but somehow I doubt it, sadly those super hero types will be held responsible for the defense rather than use their influence to gather support, inspire resistance against the oppressor, lead a truly sizeable force , but then will we criticize for copying star wars again. Easily done but unfair. Every historical battle has had its unequal sides but always had the weaker been able to take stands against the stronger.  Should the resistance in this movie franchise start a guerilla war , inflicting stings and retreating into the shadows or will we then criticize it for representing the futility of our own struggles against oppressive governments and controlling mega corporations.  Ultimately it may come over as a twee, feel good movie based on the fantasy that a small number of skilled individuals can single handedly deliver us from tirany.  'I wish'... Is the downfall of any review. Let's look at what we have, consider the concepts, the screenplay, the cinematography, the predictable script, the heroes, the obvious weak points in the oppressive regime and realize that those of us who hoped for an adult sci-fi have sadly been let down. At least there wasn't a gun toting raccoon and small taking tree in this one.
Do we think the producers and directors had to fall foul of the modern movie scourge of 'general box office appeal'.  Capitalism scores another nail in the coffin of individualism and uniqueness.

Rebel Moon Part 1: a Child of Fire - 5.7 - So from the get to I had mixed feelings about this movie. It was okay, it was not as bad as some or the internet portrayed it to be, but it was by no means great. It felt like a rushed edgier version of star wars. The fight sceens were great, that was the bread and butter, but the actual character development and plot seemed extremely rushed. For starters so the main plot the army needed to take over this planet to feed its entire army, and then a gang of like 6 people were going to take on this army. Seemed very far fetched, the twist was unexpected, but it was also a character that I most liked so far, so that caught me off guard. Overall it was worth the watch for the fight scenes and pure action alone, but this movie is no second coming of star wars or any space saga.
Hopefully the second part will be alittle better, and I will be there to check it out. The robot ended up being my favorite character for what it is worth. Official sundaynightstreaming rating of 5.7

I realy enjoyed this film. Best film I have seen this year (2024)

Part 1 and I cannot wait for part 2.

Five adults watched it, five adults enjoyed it. Of course it is founded on Kirosawa's  Seven Samurai and is not the first to do it, but does that make it any less fun?

The visuals are interesting at times especially the alien creatures and some of the ship and the sound effects are very good. For me I can't think of a single other positive, this is simply an extremely poor movie, possibly the worst I have seen in over a decade. The dialog is just atrocious, the acting at best wooden, and the plot somehow manages to be super predictable and at the same time absolute nonsense. Action scenes were so poorly done that they were immersion breaking I struggled to watch.

I didn't really care if they lived or died. The only one I warmed to was the faceless robot. There is no soul in this movie.

This story has obvious parallels to the Seen Samurai. The first part is about their selection, ending with their return to the village and the resurrection of the evil outlaw. Part two will undoubtedly continue the saga of the defense of the village/moon. Beyond bad. Incoherent, derivative, sloppy, boring. The narrative was nonsensical, the action was boring, the "stylish" cinematics were interesting‚Ä¶in 300. Now, they are just tired, massively overdone and forced.  The movie was overly long while still managing to feel like another two hours were needed to actually clue the audience into the motivations of the many characters, none of whom were anything but one dimensional caricatures of bad tropes to begin with.  I truly wish I could get the time back in my life that was wasted on this utter garage of a movie.  I knew exactly what was going to happen at the end, even while there being nothing whatsoever that could have clued the audience in. Why? Because it was the stupidest possible thing to happen and that tracked with how bad the movie was.  The only halfway decent thing about the movie were the special effects. Too bad they were so horribly wasted on this trash movie.  Now, pardon me while I leap is slow motion through the air in exactly the same way nearly every character does to come crashing down with whatever random weapon assigned to me onto something that will have zero actual consequence. Again. Oh, just for giggles, again. Once more, because it's apparently my signature and my fans won't know that it's my review without it being done again. And again. Seriously, this movie sucked.

I personally thought this movie was executed very well. Hell I liked this better than the first part of Dune and I love dune. Sci-fi movies are mostly garbage right now so, this was a breath of fresh air for me. I just think everyone should give this one a chance or even a second chance if they didn't like it the first time.

Honestly, based on the reviews, I initially anticipated this film to be nearly unwatchable. However, when my wife and I decided to give it a chance, we were pleasantly surprised.

While the film introduces viewers to a rich and expansive new universe with intricate characters and deep motivations, it is not without its flaws. The main issue lies in its duration, as it undeniably needed an extra hour or more.

The pacing feels rushed, and if the intention was to encourage viewers to watch the extended cut, it would leave me feeling somewhat deceived.

I find myself wishing this were a series rather than a film, allowing each character the opportunity to shine. With a longer runtime from the start, this could potentially evolve into a new cult classic, and the decision not to provide it with ample time was a significant oversight.

There was nothing original in this movie. I love 300 and am a huge Star Wars fan, so went in with an open mind. But this movie was Seven Samurai/Magnificent Seven set in the Star War universe, with Gamora from Marvel as the main character (Kora's backstory is exactly Gamora's- girl on a planet that is slaughtered by a megalomaniac, she is spared, adopted, and raised by said megalomaniac, becomes a super soldier, and then decides to fight against her adoptive father.) They even had an actor from Gladiator portray a general who was betrayed, and ended up in a Gladiator fighting pit in a coliseum. 

I actually really wanted to like this movie, but it was so unoriginal, and had so little character development, that I just couldn't get into it. 

It only really got my attention with the last shot of the Anthony Hopkins robot wearing the antler crown. I doubt I'll watch part two, but I'll at least read the Wikipedia plot synopsis to see what that was all about.

It appears such expectations were too high with not enough open minds to take it all in differently. At least I went into this film just open minded, lowering my expectations, without "Nit Picking" on parts of it like I used to. Because I enjoyed this for what it is and that's that. It's only a story to setup more happening in part 2, which made total sense. "Rebel Moon Part 2: The Scargiver" needs to hurry up though, because it will truly explain a lot more and go deeper. This is part 1 after all. It's a Two-Parter type of film, and patience is the key to slow-paced films like this. Hopefully more installments take place after.

I can't believe how astounding this movie is and yet how many bad reviews it has received. It does follow 'The Seven Samurai/The Magnificent Seven,' set up, I love how it has that 'Spaghetti Western' grittiness to it, but that it also has a slower pace in storytelling. Watching this movie made me feel like I was reading a good novel. The flashes of reveals in Kora's past, the mystery over who killed the Royal Family, the glimpses of how the Imperium does things. It is so rich in cultures in its story-based universe.

But anyway, despite what the haters say, Rebel Moon is a good movie with plenty of intrigue, lots of fights, and its story has a beginning, middle and an end that promises continuance into movie 2. Yes, the plot is familiar because it is a Sci-fi version of the Seven Samurai. Yes, we know what is going to happen next, but I simple can't wait for Part 2 and see what other twists Zack Synder comes up with.

Rebel Moon Part 1 has some good visuals and passable performances from the cast. There was also a clear attempt to take the world-building seriously, which I appreciate, and it didn't go down the Marvel route of forcing inane jokes and zaniness on the audience every ten seconds in case boredom sets in (these desperate attempts at humour are often the most boring part). However, that's all the praise I can give. The film would've benefited a lot if the characters had more presence and personality, as few of them stood out as memorable. At one point there's a supposedly emotional moment where one of the good guys heroically sacrifices himself, but it has little impact given that we know nothing about him and his personality is 100% interchangeable with several other characters.  The story feel formulaic at times - go to planet, recruit another hero, dump some exposition, rinse, repeat - and there's nothing in the plot you won't have seen at least a hundred times before. So this movie doesn't have anything that marks it out as excellent, but it passes the time amiably enough if you don't expect too much from it.

I've never seen a worse film, to the credit of this film.  Not only is every scene a joyless exposition dump or a slo motion fight you've seen 100 times now; but many of the elements most bad movies do ok on are also done terribly here. The Cinematography is bad, the CGI is all over the place, the dialog is horrendous, and most of the sci-fi or fantasy elements are very very obviously ripped from Dune or Star Wars. You would think that if you got the chance to make a Sci-Fi and fantasy universe you'd make your own original things, but nope. The bad guys are a mix of Nazi's and Warhammer 40k; there are Griffins, and most of the plot is just a terrible and boring assembly trying to mimic Seven Samurai.

Then you do slow motion in every battle scene. You have zero backstory for any of the character so you can't name them or care when they die. And a lot of "how convenient" twists. This is a great way to kill boredom for a couple of hours.  Is it Oscar worthy??  No.  Do I care, no.  Liked it fine.

Let's not forget, this was originally pitched as a Star Wars movie, so move past the obvious parallels and see it for what it is. Yes, it's obviously derivative (reread my previous sentence) but it's an impressive attempt to move beyond being rejected by the franchise and carry on regardless. And Sofia Boutella is absolutely awesome in it. Yes, the Empire have been replaced by half arsed Nazi knock-offs and the back story is never adequately explained, but the action set pieces are really well executed. I really don't get the complaints about the amount of exposition, I can't say I noticed it being particularly dry and if you're world building some context is necessary. There are some ropey characters that let it down a bit but overall this was enjoyable. And the trailer for part 2 looks even better.

Dreadful, forgettable, incomprehensible. I know what this film wants to be, but unfortunately, the film does not and struggles to be even a mediocre Star Wars rip off. I mean, Battle Beyond the Stars, the Roger Corman Star Wars rip from 1980 is an absolute master piece compared to Rebel Moon. This is not a rebellion worth joining.

Tent-poles of an idea with no actual story and rushed to conclude early with an unsatisfying ending. You spend the whole time waiting for a storyline that never comes. The movie started with a cheesy but perhaps promising premise, and went downhill fast. The use of freeze and slow effects were annoying and contributed nothing. The new character introductions were set across all different genres (including Western and Roman) and were timed exactly as they were completing some heroic action, strangely with no normal human reactions from the other people present, but they were cliche and predictable. Even the epic speeches were so cheesy it was painful, and nevermind their motivations. Everyone signing up with no money or incentive was just ridiculous and not thought out at all. Each scene seemed intended to push the story along as quickly as possible to get to the main battle with this elite super special team, but they shut the end of the story down early with the suddenness of a film that ran out of time or budget. It didn't leave any kind of cliffhanger or arc to give the disappointed viewer any interest in the next film. I haven't watched a film this bad in a long time.

Easily the worst big budget  scfi / action movie i've watched. In my opinion there was no character development, which meant  i didn't care about any of the characters throughout the film. There were many slow motion scenes throughout the movie relating to character moments, suggesting those scenes were meant to be poignant, and suggesting the audience should feel something for the character in that moment, but i never did. In stead of world building, i would say it was simple location building, given nothing was explained about the different planets the movie introduced. Maybe a movie that would have worked with way more character development, or before gathering the hero team together, each character had already had there own movie, to fully establish there past and audience cared about who they are, endured and would bring to a team. I didn't think much of the CGI, where most of the movie appeared to have been shot on a green screen stage, and everything looked flat. I think the movie delivers what it promised. The story in this first part of Rebel Moon is somewhat shallow but filled with good intentions. Anime and science fiction enthusiasts will be thrilled by the breathtaking scenes.

The film successfully captures the essence of both anime and sci-fi genres, creating a visually stunning experience that resonates with fans.

However, a more intricate plot development could enhance the overall storytelling. Despite its current simplicity, the film sets the stage for potential expansion in subsequent installments. The combination of stunning visuals and the promise of deeper narratives leaves audiences eager for what comes next in the Rebel Moon series.

This movie had so much potential but it wasted it. The basis for the plot is...The big empire from earth goes to the outer planets to find some rebels and harassers a small farming village of like 40 people. The farmers go out to find other people who want to defend them from the empire... which is the majority of the movie going to location and picking up people. My whole issue with it is that the people they pickup are just some randos with no story and no reason to join helping these few farmers when they have nothing to give them as a reward. The whole plot is dumb.
What they could of done is make the movie into an exponential plot which keeps increasing the scope like Gurren Lagann;  Help a farm, save a city, defend a planet, galaxy at war....

Look, it's not a cult or a classic... we've all seen the plotlines before. It is though, a great mindless bit of very well executed sci fi drama. Ed Skrein in particular puts in a gloriously OTT performance as the archetypal sadistic villain. It's just Entertainment folks, fast paced and punchy. The over harsh critics need to see this film while wearing the right glasses. Perhaps they can be excused as the film does occasionally vear towards delusional pretensions of grandiosity. If you ignore this you are left with a terrific action adventure to settle down into and enjoy.

The film definitely borrows thematically from historical science fiction westerns like Star Wars and Dune, but I don't see that as a negative. I really enjoyed the film, and I especially enjoyed the universe it is creating. If you are looking for a science fiction world to be created in film with action and the classic oppressors vs the opressed, you will enjoy this. I grow tired of "lack of character development" arguments from film critics regarding every sci-fi film, because they are complaining about something which is of minor relevance to what this film is supposed to be. It is not tied to a specific character's development. It is creating a universe. These same "character development" critics probably complain that a jeep wrangler isn't refined. If you want refined, buy a Mercedes. You buy a Jeep for the ruggedness. If you want a ton of character development, watch a historical fiction drama. If you want a new scifi universe, watch this film.

The bulk of the movie is a planet-hopping recruitment drive for NPCs. Each has a name, a micro-vignette where they demonstrate the functionality they bring to the party, and a brief dialog tree that, once clicked-through (alas, no "skip" button is available) adds them to the group. Then they fade into the background, never to be heard from or interacted with again--except to take their turn in each round of combat, sometimes accompany their attack action with a random bark of NPC dialog. 

Cool-looking armor and 5-minutes with a charming Tin Man are not enough reason to sit through this film. Skip.

The film, solely featuring aesthetically pleasing and hence sometimes uninteresting actors, encounters challenges in its direction. The execution falls short, with issues in blocking and timing affecting the overall cinematic experience. The narrative setup lacks the necessary differentiation and depth, rendering it somewhat simplistic and naive. The portrayal of culture appears to be approached with a somewhat idealized perspective, resulting in a cookie-cutter representation. Furthermore, the characters, unfortunately, come across as one-dimensional and predictable.

One is left pondering the significant craftsmanship and time invested in the creation of the story. However, the absence of a robust foundation in world-building and emotional relatability diminishes the impact of these efforts. A more comprehensive exploration of these aspects could have elevated the overall quality of the film.

Regrettably, due to the aforementioned shortcomings, I found it challenging to immerse myself fully in the film, ultimately leading to an incomplete viewing experience.
It was good,great story and good visuals.I think it deserves better critics that's why i'm ranking it 4.5 .

Some of the character development is a bit...rushed, but this fever-dream mismash of  sci-fi is pretty and engrossing. Upon a bunch of further introspection, I think I get why this movie is so divisive.  I think perhaps the professional critics and a fair bunch of the non-professionals are pretty uninspired by this film, because they want to take it as an individual piece of art, and a complete work.  This is the new normal, where a production house can take ten or twenty hours to deliver a story that once had to be encapsulated in 120 minutes or less.

This has to be viewed through the lens knowing that this film is only the first part of the narrative, and a truncated version at that.  When you only get to see the first act, you only get exposition and not the character development or building that will happen in the second act, and the full heros journey wont complete until the third.

I think the reviewers here that think this movie is great are viewing with this episodic lens.  I know that watching this, I know that there are further episodes coming, and I am curious to see how the story develops and what ideas will be presented later on.  I am also anxious to see the full release of this episode later, as this will also reveal the true vision of this first act, hidden here by the PG13 rating requirements.

They planet hop to spend 15 minutes on a supposedly secondary character for them to only have 3 more lines for the rest of the film. There are times where I don't think the main characters speak for extended periods of time. I liked the world building around the current story, the flashbacks and the aesthetics but everything else is a huge miss. Even the action feels janky and stupid with their huge lean on slow motion. Slightly interesting in the beginning but from then on, the story and the acting just goes downhill. Way too much color, and as in most of Snyders films, too much color and effects that just feel like an attempt to cover up poor storytelling and shallow characters.

Cinematography and action scenes were good. No story line to tie or show character motivations.. just paint by numbers when assembling the "heroes." A lot of potential with the story, but didn't feel fully fleshed out, hope Part 2 will improve.
Weak plot, like seriously ... however great visuals and music! Decent movie overall but nothing special. Its not one of them movies that you would like to rewatch.

Knew it was going to be bad 5 minutes in but watched anyway. Please may I have the two hours of my life bad. One of the worst movies I have ever seen. Only good scene was a combat robot shooting a bad guy in the head without aiming. Truly horrendous in all respects

It seems like it was written by a 11 year old who saw Star Wars and heard about Seven Samurai. Both long and rushed somehow. There is no difference in the walrus assembled other than how they look.  Also the Empire can fire from low orbit so what are warriors with swords and guns going to do? A single peak mountain with water falls .. where's the water coming from? Bland and every style of clothes is found on earth.

I have been very disappointed with movies for the past few years. Rebel Moon brought something fresh and interesting. I enjoyed the story, the action and the acting. I wish they would have just released the director's cut first. I cannot wait for part 2.

It's a good movie.  Yes it has a somewhat star wars vibe.... and maybe other fantasy movies.  Give it a try with an ope mind instead of expecting to hate it. 
Most movies being put out these days aren't good.  This one was.  Some people are just bitter and can't enjoy a movie.  These people giving it one star will still most likely be watching part 2.   They have to know what happens. 

I'm not getting the comparison with the robots to star wars.  Transformers maybe... in the what was it.  5th one?  Star wars.. no.  They're also not really in the movie much...

Once you accept there are no truly original ideas and that every story draws upon the many that came before‚Ä¶ you can set aside your high horse and ask yourself, "was I not entertained?" This universe was visually captivating and the story was exciting. The characters had as much depth as possible in less than 2 hrs (not a whole lot) but still had me rooting for/ against them. "A Child of Fire" has me excited for Part 2 and is worth watching for any fan of sci-fi and action/adventure.

I am not sure I have the vocabulary to describe how bad this film is. 

The script is more banal than a three year old's storybook, the plot is a hackneyed take on Stars Wars mixed with the Magnificent Seven and the characterisation is non-existent, leaving the viewer not caring at all who lives and who does not.

Add to that the feeling that the Universe has now become the Wokeverse and it is a movie to avoid at all costs.

A bunch of stuff happens to people no one cares about. 

Rebel Moon is one of those movies that focuses more on visual appeal than telling a story people care about. It's far too plot driven while the characters sit in the sidecar. It's not worth watching beyond the first act which was just ok.

Disappointing‚Ä¶ for an original‚Ä¶ it seemed anything but‚Ä¶ imagine a mix of Dune, Star Wars, and the Kriptonian design of ships & a costumes from Man of Steel with a HEALTHY dose of the pandering that was referenced in South Parks ‚ÄòPanerverse' episode & super cheesy tropes‚Ä¶. And that's my best summation of this one. Wildly disappointing & don't think I'll invest another 2 hours to see part 2.

While character development might be lacking in the second act, "Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire" is a visually stunning and action-packed film with good worldbuilding. I look forward to seeing what happens next.
The film is solid. The visuals are great. The critics are either stupid or full of hate. Maybe both. üòÇ

Its just a boring combination of other movies, but at least some nice visual effects - still it generates zero excitement, I will skip part 2.

One dimensional characters with absolutely not a thing as depth or credibility.
Mostly awful universe.
"Empire" acting like bullies on a small random village for no reason. Villain acting like a spoiled child (and this is hard to see). Trained soldiers acting like a school drama. 
People joining the crew with no reason whatsoever. Even the action parts are mediocre at best. Bits of story everywhere, that could have been fleshed out but were not.
I find it disturbing to know that a lot of people have been paid for making this thing.

Truly terrible, each character introduced gets about 2 minutes of screen time before joining the rebellion, and that's about all the character building you can expect from this movie.

The romance if it can be called that is shown by a few impassive glances.

The action scenes are unfortunately no better pointless lasers flying around while main characters stand in the open waving around sticks and swords.

The only positive is in its unrealised potential, as a world it shows a few glimpses of an expensive and interesting universe that could have been but never will.

Thin characters, yes. But still an enjoyable ride
It had great visuals but I was very bored it was basically a bunch of short stories and overly done slow motion scenes

I saw direct rip offs of Star Wars, Serenity, Starship Troopers and Lara Croft all in the first 15 minutes. Not a single original idea in it, all with Snyder's usual visual tropes. Won't be watching any directors cut and certainly no sequel.
Great watch. Dark and very entertaining. Miles ahead of recent marvel / superhero garbage coming out lately. Looking forward to part 2.
Good action film - not much plot but good characters.

Yes it borrows some elements from other movies but I don't think it is as horrible as others say, it's hard to maka a classic "fight an evil empire" story without doing something that's already been done.
My biggest grief is that the soldiers left to guard was over the top evil, to obvious. Apart from the above, a solid movie with stunning visuals. Enjoy!
Bad story telling. Super bad effects

Worst than I thought it would be.  It felt like a too serious version of Star Wars without any memorable characters or a resemblance of a coherent storyline.  Boring and not what I expected.  Pass on this one.
The story was formulaic and predictable. The villains were space Nazis. Certain plot points made no sense. Overall, there was too much cringe.
Corny and disjointed. It lacks the ability to anchor the viewer within the story. There are some visually pleasing scenes, but they do not make up for the rest of the heap.

The worst movie I've seen in recent memory. I heard it was a rejected Star Wars movie pitch and it shows; The world-building is lazy and uninspired, mostly delivered through excessive and tedious exposition and monologues. The story is yet another shameless ripoff of "Seven Samurai" with a random collection of sci-fi tropes thrown in for good measure. Two-dimensional characters and wooden acting are the final nail in the coffin. I stopped and started the movie about four times trying to give it a chance and hoping it would get good, I turned it off with about 20 minutes left because I couldn't bear it anymore.

It's nice to have a regular schmegular hero's journey movie that's sci-fi. They haven't made anything epic since the early 2000s. Ignore critics if you're a regular person. They like Atonement. ü§ÆEnough said.
Good movie. Funny and great FX.

You have to be in the right mindset for this movie. If you think you won‚Äôt like it, chances are you won‚Äôt. But if you keep an open mind you‚Äôll see the movie for what it really is. I thought it was pretty good and I‚Äôm looking forward to the other movies

From reading the reviews I guess boomers don't want their memories of star wars be besmirched.  It was great.  Casting, acting, the sets, story was a great heros journey... the best space movie since the original Guardians of the Galaxy.

This is a good-looking sci-fi movie of the typical "Hero's Journey" story genre. Are there parallels to Star Wars? Yes, because that is another "Hero's Journey" story written as a sci-fi space rebellion arc. I liked the characters and villians in this story, the acting was well done, the story is interesting and written well. I await the sequel(s) to see how it all ends...or continues.

Whilst a slow burn, I found myself on the edge of my seat. The world building & introduction of characters has created space for what is sure to be an epic saga. Whilst the storyline is something that has been told before that is the case with most sci-fi & fantasy novels, it's a hero's quest for redemption & for what is good in the world. The visuals were epic & the characters have depth that I look forward to diving into as they the journey continues.
Can't wait for part two!
Ignore the critics, this is a brilliant first part to a new space adventure. Looking forward to Part 2!

It was nice to see a new Sci Fi film, and I was really ready to enjoy it, but it was so completely unimaginative. There was so much room to develop characters more, but they didn't. The story was boring, so everything felt predictable. It took too much from other stories and just seemed lazy and cliche. My partner loved it though because he doesn't overanalyze.

It keeps a fast pace of an action movie, but the story is uninteresting and the characters shallow.  The villain goes around with a a large bone in hand while commanding a ship that is "worldender". The physics and the anachronism of the movie are so bad that would wake you up in case you fell asleep between some slow-motion combats scenes.

I think this movie is severely underrated. I love a good futuristic sci-if and this movie checks all the boxes. The special effects don't look cheap like most movies with that much background animation. The action scenes are very well done and super entertaining to watch. The fantasy aspect is captivating and visually appealing.

Rebel moon-part 1: a child of Fire meh, I watched it. Alot of obvious, see me camera angles. Music ok, not great. The usual underdog , treachery, back-stabbing underhandedness. Supposed to be #1 in filums. Underwhelming.
6.5/0.

Absolutely awful. A bunch of random sci-fi and fantasy tropes smooshed together with some decent special effects. Story was ridiculous. Fight scenes make less than 0 sense. I would trust an 8th grader to come up with a better movie plot.
Amazing movie. Disney screwed up letting this one slip by.
Interesting movie and characters
Backstory: The Movie
Good sci-fi and have potential story
This film felt extremely generic as a big sci-fi fan I wanted to like it but it just came down to the same old tropes with un interesting characters.
This movie is pretty good.  I'm not sure what people want. There hasn't been a war based sci fi film that isn't a remake that got good reviews in forever.  Be thankful that this one is pretty good.
Loved it. Something different for a change.

Basically a remake of 'Battle beyond the Stars'. Some good visuals, baffling accent choices (yes of course the villain went to Eton!), clearly laying some storylines for future parts, but ultimately, nothing to justify the money spent.
No better than many straight to TV/Streaming films that cost a fraction of this budget.  Glad I didn't pay to see at the cinema, but entertaining enough to watch through.

It's classic space opera. The problem being that if already with the pilot , it accumulates lots of negatives : far too many unnecessary lengths & narrative exposition which weighs down the already not ""good"" pace. As much as the 1st fight in the camp is nice & punchy. The 2nd (in the inn with the badguy wanting to fck one of the characters), but it's sooo slow... A sensation that will come back, ofteen üôÑüòñ
Watched because of the great actors. Movie really sucked. Storyline was very weak just like the movie in general.

Loved the imagery, story, and characters. While familiar it was still unique in its undertone focused on empathy and kindness as n such a harsh world. Beautifully filmed and fight scenes choreographed.

Justice League vs the Space Nazis.
Poorly shot, weirdly lit, medley of every sci-fi trope available, set against a backdrop of cheap CG and peppered with wooden acting.
Excellent movie, fresh different yet everything you want in a sci Fi movie
I watched the entire movie!
Forget about critic's reviews, the movie is great

Love the start of a new story. The visuals of each planet has its own beauty. There are also shots in a scene that make you wonder if a hidden image or meaning exists in that shot. There are characters in this film that one can identify with. Some of these characters, you just love to hate. And there's still more back story and future story to tell with these characters. I understand that Part One has set up the team. I am so ready for part 2.
Universe is cool would have liked to see more than just a pit stop at planets
Thoroughly enjoyed it. Many artful scenes.

I can't really describe how boring this movie felt. Everything seemed so generic. I felt no involved at all with the charatcers, that felt incredibly dumb at times. I mean, is it so hard to write something a little interesting? Slow motions and lens flares are not enough to make it a decent movie. I usually tend to finish watching even things i don't like, but i'm not going to watch part two.

I don't even know where to start with this one. The pacing was horrible, they had a crazy over-reliance on slow motion, they introduced a bunch of super interesting characters with little to no backstory or development, and the main character is, and I cannot stress this enough, literally Gamora, but instead of being adopted by Thanos, she was adopted by the empire from Star Wars. This movie was horrible.
I liked Rebel Moon, it was not perfect but it was a fun watch.
Very entertaining.  A fun ride from start to finish
What is wrong with you guys. I can't even remember in the last 15 years when someone delivered an SCI-FI like Rebel Moon. This movie should be above 70%.
How did they ever get funding for this? An unending row of cliches. Unbearably bad.
Give me back two and a half hours of my life!! My god!!! what ever expectetion you have for this movie, make it lower!.

Not enough time given to develop each of the characters, and sooo full of fantasy stereotypes. This is a story that would probably be better as a 3-book trilogy and then another trope can be checked. Visually pretty.
For once, the pro critics are right.
300 meets star wars love them both and love rebel moon.

The lack of creativity is strong here, the cynical way of trying to get away with copying various science fiction masterpieces verbatim. So much visual garbage, unnecessary VFX abuse, and painful slow motion.
And Snyders said his cut is the best? Save time and avoid this mistake.
Dull, wooden script and acting and so much slo-mo you have time to take a nap during action scenes.
Well done, but nothing new. It's pretty formulaic...although I'm looking forward to the sequel.

Zack should let actual writers do the writing and not force them to insert his ideas into the narrative. EVER.
Rebel Moon is nothing but a collection of sci-fi/fantasy tropes, cliches, dressed up with tired and over-used designs swipes from video games, comics, and other better movies and tv shows.
Rebel Moon is absolute garbage!
YUK!
I am not a big scifi person but I actually enjoyed this and looking forward to next part of the series.
For first time it is huge thumbs up. Nice visual effects. I will watch again in few months. Definitely waiting for the sequel coming in April 2024!
Maybe it's so bad, it's good? The dialogue is cheesy (and thereby hilarious) and overall it's stupid. I watched the whole thing.

It was visually very nice but felt like a mash up of star wars, guardians of the galaxy and Dune. The winged creature was stright up from Hogwarts but in night mode. If some one hasn't seen any of the movies, they would find it cool. Story line is pretty formulaic so much so that you can predict whats gonna happen in the next movies.

I delayed watching this after reading the critic's review, so was surprised by how much I enjoyed Rebel Moon.  Yes, it's derivative, but so is almost every modern sci fi film I've ever watched, with the possible exception of Blade Runner and Inception.
The backstory narratives were important to set the scene for the series, the acting was good and pleasantly low-key, the dialogue was nicely minimalist, the cinematography was wonderful and the action was gripping.  
And the Magnificent Seven was an excellent remake, so using Seven Samurai as inspiration is a bonus.
We need to stop with the whining Star Wars fanboy reviews or we'll never see Part 2.
It's like watching a bad superhero movie....meh

This was nothing more than a rip off of the very first Star Wars movie. Rebels. Weird music and characters in a bar. Finding rouge pilot to fly you to look for more future  rebels. Fight off empire fleet while vastly out numbered. Acting that's not even that good. And to make it even worse, enough CGI to choke a horse. If you want to see this kind of movie, watch Star Wars. 100 times better.

It looks great, and if you're inclined, you can spend your time guessing which movie a scene has come from or see how many of the actors appeared in Game of Thrones. But to be honest it is over two hours long and that's only part one!! I don't think we're gonna make it.
Great story A lot of fun to watch
Awesome movie definitely can't wait for part two
I'm glad I didn't pay money to see this in a theater. Even starting out with no expectations, it was still a disappointment.

What did I just saw ..

I was entertained. Yes, it's derivative (not nearly so much as John Wick 4), but I liked all the movies it stole from, so, yes, I was entertained and look forward to the second half.
very good start to the saga... waiting for the sequel which seems promising

If you like watching other people play video games then you might enjoy this. There is no acting required for this film. The dialogue is either voice over exposition or grunts and orders during fight scenes. This is an idea for a movie but not a realized vision.
The movie was not a masterpiece but entertaining and hopefully it will get better with part 2. The universe has potential. I like   the movie.
Poor Battle beyond the Stars rip off with a modern diverse cast
If you've seen enough of Zack Snyder's movies this is typically how they are. As long as you go into knowing his style you'll really enjoy the movie. Ignore the critics, the movie is a great watch
First 5 minutes was a little worried, but quickly found myself drawn in. Fun universe he created very star wars meets cyberpunk. I'm excited to see the next part in April.

Visually stunning. It is a good idea, but the choppy story weakens the film and the (at times) patronizing dialog suffers. You'll get mad at the film's potential to be great, but in the end, you'll have enjoyed watching it.
Awful character development/writing. Worst movie I've seen in a while.
Boring storyline.. a duplicate of familiar stories.

There are movies made as if the setting and the heroes inspire and invigorate the authors. This movie is opposite; i got a feeling, personally, that the authors were as much bored and disgusted with it as was I.

Superb special effects cannot help a story built on tropes of the Star Wars series. Rebellion by downtrodden characters against an evil intergalactic empire, a lovable robot, a weird assemblage of aliens in a space bar etc. There are certainly moments of a little tension but the outcome is never in doubt. Add to this that the inconsistencies are alarming - a society where people plough with horses, hunt elk and cook over fires, yet have automatic sliding doors and electric lights. Spend your time on something better.

Tries hard with plots and lines from
other various sci-fi movies but fails. Some good effects but not that engaging.

Its pretty. Its familiar. It's mildly entertaining and will fill in two hours. Don't come here looking for anything original though. 

Take the best, most cliched parts of all the sci-fi and classic western movies ever made and put them together into one sci-fi movie. Be sure to go extra heavy on the "Star Wars" franchise. Take inspiration and the best bits from everything from slang and clothing from gangster movies, mafia movies, action movies and even a smidgen of Harry Potter beasts and Voila! You've got it. Its Rebel Moon! 

Entertaining, pretty, but not an original bone in its body...

This movie gave me diarrhea

I cannot understand any of the hate towards this movie. Quality acting, quality graphics, quality production. Predictable - sure - but in no way hurts the amazingness and enjoyment of the experience. Watch it and enjoy and stop being such critics!
Not as bad as critics make it out to be, i actually watched the whole thing.
Writing was god awful, not sure how much that affected the really bad acting but it certainly didn't help.

The visual effects were superb throughout with compelling characters and outstanding performances, especially Cara. The plot and setting reminds you of several universes but it never detracted from the viewing experience. I thought one scene at the Trading City bar was reminiscent of the Star Wars Cantina but that was the only blatant borrowing I saw. Obviously it is about a group of Rebels that rebel against an Empire, so you can see some of the parallels to Star Wars. I also felt it had some homage to Dune and Chronicles of Riddick. The movie plays quickly at 2:15 I never felt it dragged and let me just say there is a twist near the end that surprised me and something unexpected. I understand this is a multi-part series so hopefully it will develop a following. If you love Sci-fi, give it a chance and enjoy it for what it is and do not try to overanalyze it.

I would give it a 4 out of 5 for what it's worth. It was obviously a Star Wars rip off but it was a rip off I enjoyed while I hated the character development, pacing and length it was a movie I enjoyed and excited to see the future. One of the reasons why I am writing a positive review is because it is only the start of something and has great potential.

The writing/dialogue felt very juvenile and the multiple grandstanding slow motion sequences felt cringe and pointless.

I wasn't impressed.
The plot is bugs life in space. They did get warriors instead of circus performers.

- RebelMoon pg13 c√≥mo pel√≠cula cumple todas las expectativas, es entretenida, tiene muy buena acci√≥n, buen VFX, hermosa cinematograf√≠a, y un excelente score, una problem√°tica bastante relacionable y con una historia facil de seguir. 
Esta versi√≥n abarca lo suficiente en cuanto historia y desarrollo para introducirnos a este universo y a estos personajes y justamente al mostrar solo lo suficiente para comprender la trama y personajes te hace querer conocer y ver mas d√°ndole a la audiencia el ideal de seguir enganchado y querer ver la parte dos de esta historia y el futuro corte del director para indagar en el pasado de los rebeldes y en el trasfondo de la historia a√∫n mejor; Rebel Moon va directo al punto, una din√°mica que se puede percibir tal vez apresurada pero para lo que intenta ser esta versi√≥n lo logra muy bien, una introducci√≥n √©pica pero sencilla al p√∫blico a un nuevo universo.

- RebelMoon as a pg13 movie meets all expectations, it is entertaining, it has very good action, good VFX, beautiful cinematography, and an excellent score, a very relatable issue with an easy to follow story.
This version covers enough history and development to introduce us to this universe and these characters and precisely by showing just enough to understand the plot and characters it makes you want to know and see more, giving the audience the ideal of staying hooked and wanting to see part two of this story and the future director's cut to delve into the rebels' past and the background of the story even better; Rebel Moon gets straight to the point, a dynamic that can perhaps be perceived as rushed but for what this version tries to be, it achieves it very well, an epic but simple introduction for the audience to a new universe.
Poor character development and boring.

Quite possibly the worst movie I've ever seen.  It's not original at all, it's directly a 1 for 1 rip of Battle Beyond the Stars for the first half.  Nothing in this movie is actually original.  It's as if the writer took his favorite clips of movies he's watched and fed them into an AI script generator and filmed what came out the other side.   Also 75% of the film is purposely blurry for artistic reasons, but only served to annoy me.

Not only did it steal ideas and styles from the likes of Star Wars, Star Trek, and Lord of the Rings, but it looks like they also stole their makeup and props.
Add that to the two characters with absolute awful impersonations of Northern Ireland accents, for whatever that was meant to add to the story.
It was a god awful movie.
Please writers and actors, go back on strike. Looking back, that was a much happier time for the viewer.

This movie is like a very bad composition of Star Wars, Star Trek, Ghost in the Shell, Warhammer 40k, and even some Mythology element (wtf). This is definitely one of the worst movies I have watched in 2023, if not the worst...

This movie was so good, unbelievable! Graphics were great. A nice mix of medieval times and new technology. The story was beautiful and the fights were incredibly good! Can't wait for part 2 of the movie!!
Loved it! Can't wait for the full length R rated version to see more!
Terrible, save yourself the embarrassment of having a part 2.
It just wasn't my cup of tea

It definitely gives off Star Wars vibes, however the story/plot is what I'd call decent, it at least keeps you watching. I am disappointed it's in Parts as I'd prefer more finalization. The ending is a bit unrealistic and frustrating. The CGI is a little "meh" during some scenes, but overall visually appealing. Some parts are predictable almost painfully so - but doesn't hurt the overall movie, the acting could use a little polishing, as some "serious/dramatic" scenes were almost comical and I'm sure that was not intended. I do plan on watching further Parts for finalization to the story as it does have my attention as I'd like to see where this story goes.

Seem like Copy paste from random movies. Magic sifi mixed with olden times wtf. It's like chatgpt created it.

This movie is great. A great start to a new Universe. I can't wait to see more. Amazing visuals and great action.

Agree with other reviews - still enjoyed the movie and will watch second one but fails to establish an enduring IP - liberally takes from other SciFi IPs (StarWars , Foundation even Potter to name a few ) and does not invest enough in character development - General Titus, Tarlak , Nemesis and others all deserved more time in their background to make us care and get vested .

Derivative in details, but solid story core, even if based off of Seven Samurai. I think this would have been better as a series. More time for character development would have benefited the story. Very entertaining, just don't go into this movie thinking Star Wars. Be open minded.

Zack Snyder's "Rebel Moon," catapults audiences into an expansive galactic odyssey that blends dazzling visuals with an intriguing narrative. As a fan of Snyder's distinctive style, I eagerly delved into this space epic. Snyder's signature visual flair is evident in every frame, elevating the movie to a cinematic spectacle. A Child of Fire serves as the inaugural installment in a series of adventures. One notable aspect is its ambitious attempt to construct a comprehensive universe; however, its drawback lies in the challenge of functioning seamlessly as a standalone movie. The film's emphasis on universe-building, while commendable, may hinder its effectiveness as an independent cinematic experience.

This is such a dumb movie.  It started off dumb and just kept getting dumber.  A world with spaceships that can destroy civilization and bend space don't need bushels of grain from psuedo futuristic farmers that use horses to till, and a fireplace to warm their homes yet have a metal electronic sliding doors that I assume use electricity.  Of course how can I forget the weird kings army that has uniforms that are a cross between a nazi army, ancient Persian military looking alien advisors and halo dressed warriors.    Fancy special effects can't make up for this terrible movie.    Dumb dumb dumb.

Derivative and largely unoriginal yes; but better acting, sets, story and acting than most of the Star Wars Films. It's worth a watch.
Visually stunning.  Being a long time Sci-fi fan, this has elements from all the classics.  It also has a Destiny feel to it, IMHO.

There's a lot of logic gaps.  Why would a dreadnought ship want to buy 10 bushels of something from a farm in the middle of nowhere?  There's almost zero humour, why not tell a few jokes?  
People shouting and running when blasters are being fired is silly, they're not running faster than the plasma bullets.  They probably need a lightsaber type person to deflect bullets to make it interesting because it doesn't matter how strong someone is they can be easily shot and killed.
The imagery is impressive and it's emotionally moving in parts (rebel commanders death), just the tone is almost continuously orchestral.  It's hard not to be impressed but it does let itself down.

Finally, why are the evil guys all talking with Irish accents?
Nothing new or original and the slow motion in every action sequence gets old very fast.

There's no one else to blame!  If it were free and running in the background while you were on a treadmill, that's about the right level of investment.  Definitely no need or desire to see a Part 2.

I can see why the "top critics" panned this film, I nearly gave up after the first few minutes as it looked like it would be a weak, low budget, boring affair. BUT how wrong I was! Once the characters are introduced and developed over the first part of the film, the pace slowly ramps up and up and I got carried along on what is an exciting ride with great characters (as good as those in the super hero movies- and you could almost see this film in manga form with its style and action sequences. I'm glad I stayed the distance- and can't wait for part 2 already!!! Don't believe the downbeat critic reviews, which whilst understandable from the first few minutes, I think are disappointed it's a fairly simple premise. Like Star Wars was lol- a fabulous film but at its core good vs bad, albeit done with incredible mastery by all concerned. Give Rebel Moon a chance, I don't think you'll be disappointed, and maybe you'll love it as much as I do. Bring it on‚Ä¶

Just terrible. Derivative story, woeful script, gormless acting, laughable CGI, bizarre directorial choices, a lens flare for every scene, aeons of exposition, leaden pacing. From the opening sequence when our hero is lovingly grasping fistfuls of soil in a quasi-sexual manner, through the tortuously uninteresting assembly of the seven nouveau samurai, and on (and on) through the swamp of dull set-up for part two, this film goes nowhere and does very little, and what it does do, takes twice as long as it should. It wouldn't know an original idea if it jumped up and bit it. Unless it's out of morbid curiosity, I'd avoid this lumpen mishmash of other people's poorly rendered ideas at all costs. 2 hours and 14 minutes of your life you'll never get back.

Overall an enjoyable film, though it is a bit derivative and is strangely paced. The main set pieces are very watchable and have some interesting visual touches. There's a lot going on, and it seems that it would have been better as a miniseries with time to flesh out each of the characters. The general structure of the seven samurai is to spend time building up the characters of the supporting squad so that their eventual deaths are meaningful. Here, we spent a little too much time on the bad guys and search for the squad, rather than on the squad themselves.  Thus, we really don't care enough about the crew. Perhaps that work will be done in part two.

In any case, the visuals and action were enough diversion for a few hours.

Look, did I enjoy it? Yes, it was worth the watch. But was it great? No, far from it actually. The best I could describe how I feel about this film was that it felt like a sequel film. You get into these characters lives with barely any context or build up, which creates the inability to buy in to the entire story. I loved the casting, they had the talent for an amazing film, but scripting and character depth kept it from that. This could have easily been a three part series. Again, if you're just looking for a film to watch on a rainy day, watch it.

This movie reminded me of a story I have wrote when I was 12 years old. Same storyline, great threat, collect x,y and z, betrayal and so on. And of course due to my age they lacked character development, and context for anything, no memorable characters or no meaningful relationship developed. Back then I remember that after reading it again I figured it was not so great so I decided to do with it what you do with garbage stories, toss them in a drawer and forget about them or even better repurpose the paper. Little did I know it had the exact requirements for a Hollywood  movie and at an early age I have written something equivalent with one of the great writers in the industry. Oh my, how the quality of movies and storytelling has dropped.

Firstly, in terms of the rating I think 7/10 is more precise and reasonable. Not sure how ppl are giving it a 1/5 or anything around or less than that fractionally. Those reviews, to me, seem driven by some peculiar emotional mix; "worst movie" or things of that sort, I sense, are written by folks that either don't watch many films, had a bad day, or don't know how to assess films like this.
Now to the movie; it's a hodgepodge of parts of other cinematic IP, which is not a novel notion considering the director openly stated that it was pitched as a Star Wars spinoff. Can't quite tell if it feels more like star wars, dune, or, at times, a Western but, for sure, it doesn't feel too original. The dialogue is o.k. I was expecting more/better, however, the acting is stellar. The cast picks up for any slack, and so, it seems appropriate and relevant to identify that and take it into account with gradation. It's worth noting the movie has its share of puzzles it never quite places, and, side persons i feel it should invest more time in expanding on. Film is littered with a lot of interesting pictorial angles. 
Act 2 is best IMO.
If you're looking for space fighting aesthetic grandeur and a decent plot this is for you.

Meh. As Yogi Berra said, it's like deja vu, all over again. While it had high production values and fine acting, the plot seemed unremarkable, familiar, derivative - mainly of Star Wars (even the blasters make the same beeyoo-beeyoo-beeyoo sound).  About every 20 minutes I'd raise the remote to switch away.  Right then a kick-butt fight would erupt, so I'd stay, eventually raise the remote. Another fight.  Warcraft uses the same trick to keep players playing. The main character Kora (Sofia Bouttela) is believably intense, athletic and can kick the horns off 8 charging rhinos. The antagonist Nobel (Ed Skrein) is suitably sociopathic in his role as an admiral of a (too) Naziesque strike force from the Motherworld. He plans to extract one harvest from the farming world Kora is on and then wipe out the population - an idea that makes no economic sense - but galvanizes Kora to assemble a ragtag army of rebels.  This whole hero's journey has been done a billion times before. You can tell where this story is going the moment you lay eyes on Kora fitting into her adopted farming village like Riddick into an all-girls kindergarten class. The plot is like Muzak where the tune is familiar but the highs and low have been taken out.
Mama, this is garbage!

Ok, so I have really mixed feelings around this film. Definitely has some similarities with Star Wars, and other SiFi films but has it's own story. Really great effects, and perfectly designed sets. Where it falls short is the plot and characters. Outside of Charlie's (Played Jax from SOA) character, they simply aren't interesting. The plot for recruitment of the "Rebel" force feels rushed. I think the bones of this story had promise, but the lead protagonist and most of the supporting cast just aren't interesting enough to pull you in. I'm invested enough to watch the second movie, but I don't have high hopes.

2) A good movie is more than a collection of action scenes strung together with monologues and narration.

Lots of interesting concepts but not put to good use. Plot makes very little sense.  For example, the evil empire is evil for the sake of being evil.

Evil Empire: Hey we can sell/give you farming robots so you can have massive yields.
Farmers: Naw we want to work by hand, we are just a tiny farming community on this planet and don't exactly grow much food.

A semi-intelligent evil empire would say, okay, cool. Then take their farming robots and farm the hell out of a different part of the planet to get the food they need. Maybe offering to pay for some time with their master gardener.

But nope, instead they kill a couple people, and drop off their most sadistic troops to ensure their plan goes to hell in a hand basket right away. Protagonists can't be chronically stupid and yet have a track record of amazing competence.

It simply isn't very good.

Great visual effects with some good action sequences but character development so shallow they'd drown in a puddle. No real character development, weak script writing which sadly lets down some great actors. If it had a better script this could have been a great film.

Think "Bug's Life" as a space opera with aliens and humans. 
Big bad guys come to take the annual harvest. 
Threaten to hurt everyone if they do not provide a full harvest. 
One of the farmers takes on the role of finding even meaner 'bugs' /people to fight the bad guys away from their farming community.... 
Sword wielding Ninja mercenary named Nemesis 
Bad Han Solo owns a ship 
Roman themes throughout - including a general or two 
A displaced prince who can speak to fantastic beasts (and apparently can handle the massive thermal changes without ever wearing a shirt, but he needs pants 
A bad guy who is killed and then restored to life with a new mission to bring back the kidnapped/adopted daughter of Thanos... wait, no, but kind of... 

... aside from the thin veil of plagiarism, the special effects are pretty good. The story telling is subpar. I watched this because it got 'great' reviews. I see that I was maliciously misinformed.

It was a fun ride! I highly recommend!

It was entertaining but it was definitely overhyped. Some things seemed off, like the story itself, the random slow-mo scenes, and none of the characters had any chemistry or connection. That said, it was visually entertaining, the action scenes were fun (minus the overdone and unnecessary slow-mo scenes), and the series has potential if it's steered back on track. I give it 4 stars because it was a fun watch, and because we need more shows of this production quality on streaming services. Though I hope they can learn from their mistakes.

Awful as a whole. Characters are boring and forgettable. Every scene was stolen from some other sci fi or fantasy great. The only thing this had was great graphics, but with that it also created probably the worst part of the show which is the fact that the fight scenes were ultra violent but only had PG 13 outcomes. In multiple scenes arms were broken, but not really broken. The scenes occur in what should be very gruesome but no gore whatsoever. It just didn't fit together. At least in like a PG 13 Marvel movie the combat matches the outcome. A lot of hype for the ultimate let down.

Awesome sci Fi film!!!  I loved it.  Really looking forward to the next part.

I had high hopes for this, and it's not bad per se. Truly beautiful, action was amazing! It was just too much content in too little time. Jumping from planet to planet, person to person so quickly I couldn't remember main characters' names, let alone feel a compelling connection to them. This would have worked far better as a 6 or even 8 part series so that each world/character could have been explored more in depth. Such huge potential only to over pack it and miss a lot of depth. I will still check out part 2 but can't get over my disappointment at imagining what could have been.

The movie was very appealing visually, but the lack of entertaining writing and borrowed tropes alone can't make a good movie out of a less than appealing narrative. The over abundance of slow motion makes this movie incredibly boring. It is predictable and cannot be carried by its amazing cast alone
I feel like this is gonna be fodder for Mystery science theater 3000.

This movie was one of those "epic" movies. Sure, the storyline felt like it was on fast forward at times, and the acting could've been a little better, but this movie satisfies the fantasy of fighting an intergalactic war that isn't too far fetched.
Loved this. Can't wait for part two.  The slow burn here and there doesn't bother me.  It's setting up part 2.

I believe the critics got this one wrong, they could only credit the visuals which are epic, but it creates a brand new IP were a female protagonist who has to face the demons of her past to save her future, fantastic!! Avoids the Mary Sue Star Wars narrative also doesn't get bogged down in the metadology of the force or explaining the ability of their warrior, the narrative that ultimately killed star wars over explaining the force and restricting the abilities to someone who was force sensitive. Thankfully this new space opera creates a story of survival and resistance that is both familiar and fresh!! The movie has Star Wars, Avatar and The Matrix inspired moments, moments that shocked cinema and it's definitely recaptured in Rebel Moon!!

It has an OK start to it, although the accents of the bad soldiers was a bit on the nose.

Then it turns into Seven Space Samurai but unlike the original where you understand what they're doing and why it's a lot more ambiguous here. In the original you understand what both sides want and how they plan on achieving it. 

In the original it's a village full of people guided by the ronin in a defensible position. They are against a gang of bandits. This is a winnable fight.

In Seven Go To Space they're defending a village against the equivalent of The Empire in Star Wars. The second they encounter hardship they could just destroy the village. Or the entire planet. Our heroes even seem to acknowledge this... but still don't seem to have any kind of plan beyond join forces and defend the village.

So after they leave the village pretty early in the movie it's just a recruitment drive. We go to next guy and collect for team. We have no plan. It's shockingly boring.

Ok so here we go. The sets looked fake and were so damn bland, the cgi was good sometimes but mostly not, you could tell where the sets ended and the green screen started, the plot was dumb and the practical effects were horrible, and too much slowmo. A very average film from an extremely overrated director.

A test of the degree of imagination shown in a sci-fi film is whether it could equally have been done as a cowboy movie. "Rebel Moon Pt. 1" could have, and the movie would have been "The Magnificent Seven" (1960, 2016, 1998-2000 as a TV series, or indeed "Seven Samurai" of 1954), because the plot is err.... identical. And I expect the plot of the second half will be identical too. So if you have ever seen any of those and a spaceship taking off, you don't need to see this movie (OK, some of the spaceship imagery is very good). But I have to wonder whether anyone was actually paid for "writing" the script :-)

As I watched "Rebel Moon Part 1," I couldn't help but feel disappointed by what unfolded on the screen. The film, which promised an exciting sci-fi adventure, was marred by a series of critical flaws. Firstly, the script was a letdown, filled with clich√©s and lacking in meaningful character development. This made it hard for me to connect with or even care about the characters and their journey. Additionally, the pacing was painfully slow, with numerous scenes dragging on without adding anything significant to the story. Although the visual effects were technically impressive, they often felt excessive and seemed to compensate for the lack of a strong narrative. The performances, too, left much to be desired, failing to bring any real depth or nuance to the lackluster script. All these elements combined made "Rebel Moon Part 1" a forgettable and rather frustrating viewing experience, falling short of the captivating sci-fi epic it aimed to be.

This is an objectively terrible movie. That said, it is a really fun drinking game movie. Get a group of family or friends and have a drink everytime you spot a scene, character or storyline ripped from another movie. If you know your sci-fi and fantasy movies you will be quite drunk by the end! 

I am frankly quite amazed a second instalment is imminent. The acting was very poor, the effects were ok (some effects were terrible), the characters were ridiculous, and the story line wholly unoriginal. As a new cast member came on screen, an Asian lady, we took bets on whether or not she was going to be a ninja. Sure enough, Asian lady is a ninja with lightsabers. 

Skip this movie, unless you watch it is a group for some drinking fun.

Thoughtless, mind numbing trash. It feels weird to say a movie both has way too much exposition and at the same time absolutely none. The viewer is spoon fed melodramatic flashback scenes of over delivered dialogue to establish the main character's tragic trope of a back story, while every other character is given a short segment of an over the top action sequence and some crumbs of dialogue. Only to take up arms and join the party without any meaning or reason, then getting shoved off screen, exit stage right.

Sci-fi fans will quickly realize that everything put on screen by the design department is something they've seen done before. From costumes that look directly ripped out of other franchises, to weapons so uninspired and unoriginal your brain will be convinced they pulled them off another set. 

Backgrounds often appear as flat, wide open poorly rendered cgi spaces that serve to remind your brain that nothing on screen is real, and none of this matters. The special effects look like mid 2000s video game cutscenes that seem intentionally blurred to hide the mistakes.

Nobody will be talking about this movie a month from now, and if there's any justice in the world this flop will serve as a reminder to future sci-fi writers and directors that if you want to start your own IP you have to be at least somewhat original.

A disclaimer. My general mode of watching a movie or tv show is all about my entertainment. I do not fancy myself as a wanna-be critic and I don't spend the majority of my viewing time critically dissecting the plot line, the acting or finding a reason to punish the director for some past sin or disappointment.  Having set that as my viewing criteria I will say this movie entertained me. There was plenty of action and the universal design pleased my science fiction sensibilities.  Yes, the plot line had a familiarity to it but I enjoyed it just the same. I had no expectations for a more provocative level of sex or violence so I had no disappointment there. I will endeavor to watch part 2 when it comes out.
