This movie can only be reviewed with a pros and cons list as the polarity of what was good and what was bad was so dramatic, I feel the need to break it up. 

Pros:
*The graphic design of this movie is unbelievably good! Whomever designed the worlds and graphically created them, did one of the best jobs I have ever seen. The work they did into making the worlds feel so realistic were phenomenal, I was beyond impressed. This maybe some of the best imagery I have ever seen in a movie ever. +10 Stars
*The movie soundtrack has a very well balanced epic nature to it and felt very dramatic, but still felt smoothly placed along the different scenes of the movie. 
+4 Stars

Cons:

*The main female actress was not good, her acting was atrocious. What really ruined it for me is that it is an action movie. It was abundantly obvious that she had zero athletic ability, even her "run" looked non athletic. It was weird and made it very hard to take her serious in the action scenes. Triple camera angles bouncing around and slow motion scenes for days to make up for her inability to do any real action choreography. Also, this actress is like 90lbs. I very much doubt shes able to do any hand to hand combat yet they kept putting her in scenes where she is........ 
-5 stars
* Plot armor......more plot armor....and.....well more plot armor. I am convinced that a 10 year old wrote this plot line. It just does not have one real piece of developed plot. It was beyond cliche, there were no surprises, everything was obvious, and half the time the plot made no sense. The "collecting" warriors montage was so dumb....I almost turned the movie off on the "gryphon scene". I love gryphons, but there was no need to add this part to the movie other than to attract that small portion of sub 80 IQ viewers.
-5 Stars
*Acting. Almost every major actor in the movie, besides the main actress who is horrible, are usually really good actors/actresses. It hurt my heart to see some of my most favorite actors and actresses going through the motions as they participated in this horrendously bad movie. You could feel that they just were not in it. I recognize I know next to nothing about directing a movie, and at this point I am 100% certain I could make a better film. This is absolutely painful to watch. 
-5 Stars

Conclusion:
This movie is absolutely horrible. What makes this movie even more terrible is the fact that the creators of the imagery and music did a beyond well done job, only to have all their hard work just flushed right down the toilet with terrible writing/directing. This movie had some amazing potential and could have rocked the socks off of any viewer, but the never ending plot holes, the terrible acting, the unrealistic and mediocre main protoganist, the sidelined better actors/actresses, and the cliche ending were absolutely deflating. The producers/writers/directors should be ashamed of themselves.
It's a good flick. I'm not sure where all the negative comments are coming from, but I started the film with an open mind and found out it's good.

The first 35 minutes of the movie begins with a decent plot, a group of vulnerable colonists are threatened by a military force. They must give up their crops or die. The characters and dialog were compelling and it seemed to be the start of a decent movie. However, from there the story devolved into a shamockery of the worst kind. The hero assembles a group of tough guy (and gal) fighters, painfully one at a time, to save the colonists. Each new fighter is more simple, over the top, and under-developed than the last. The script quicly becomes a total effortless joke. The move stumbles incoherently from one scene to the next as it assembles a league of extrodinary goofs. The final fight sequence is so hard to believe and painful to watch that I had to fast forward thru it or risk vomitting. This movie is an insult to sci-fi fans.

This film stands as a profound disappointment, a stark contrast to the expectations set by its promising premise. It's plagued by a multitude of shortcomings, the most glaring of which is its poorly structured plot. The storyline meanders without clear direction, leaving the audience bewildered and disengaged. The script is another weak point, filled with dialogue that feels artificial and forced, further detracting from the movie's potential to resonate with its viewers.

In terms of performances, the actors seem to struggle, unable to breathe life into their one-dimensional characters. This lack of depth in character development results in a failure to evoke any emotional investment from the audience. The interactions between characters feel stilted and unnatural, exacerbating the film's overall lack of cohesion.

Furthermore, the direction of the movie is lackluster. It's evident that there's a missing sense of vision or creative flair, which leaves the film feeling uninspired and tedious. This is compounded by the subpar cinematography and special effects, which are neither innovative nor particularly well-executed. Instead of enhancing the storytelling, they feel like afterthoughts, failing to add any real excitement or visual appeal.

Even the soundtrack, which often serves as a redeeming feature in many films, is unremarkable and forgettable in this case. It neither complements the scenes nor adds any additional layers to the narrative.

Overall, the movie is a significant letdown. It fails to deliver on many fronts, from storytelling and character development to technical aspects like cinematography and special effects. The end result is a film that is not only unsatisfying but also forgettable, lacking the elements necessary to make it a worthwhile cinematic experience.

This movie had so much potential but ultimately fell flat. I'm optimistic for the sequel because it is an interesting world to create a compelling story in and all the pieces are there it just comes down to the actual story and the development of the characters. 

My primary issues are Kora's character development being done entirely in voice over flashbacks which messed up the pacing of the movie; the complete lack of characterization of everyone on the elite team they gathered; and the climax taking place at an unnamed undisclosed trade depot, which drastically reduced the stakes of protecting the farm planet the primary conflict was based around.

The biggest positive was Kai. The acting was spot on, the costume choice and props he had made him intriguing and I don't want to spoil anything but his twist had a good set up and payoff.

I hope the sequel is better because I really believe it can be good.

How did they get away with so many blatant plagiarised elements from so many different movie franchises? The hippogriff from Harry Potter, Queen of the Aracnos from Dr Who just 2 small examples and why oh why is Charlie Hunnam attempting a Northern Ireland accent with emphasis on the word attempting. Well acted, great effects and cinematography but all the time I was distracted by remembering which other film was being ripped off in virtually each scene and let's not forget the massive overuse of slow motion.

I truly had high hopes for this film and its sequel, but I am sad to say I was severely underwhelmed and disappointed by this attempt at a space opera of sorts.  First, the visuals, while elaborate and meant to be "eye candy" were ruined by poor decisions such as Zack Snyders continuous use of slow motion throughout the film. All the major battles/action packed moments were ruined by ridiculous slow motion cuts.  The characters were really hard to "get to know" and almost there to just create an ensemble of "rebels" yet you barely get to know anything about them. The movie was slow, yet jumped quickly from location to location in an effort to fit in as much as possible in the short window of time the movie was allotted.  Sadly, I went into this movie with zero idea of what it was about and was open to just enjoy another "Star Wars" like film and I hate to say how utterly disappointed I was.  There was basically nothing redeeming about this film and unfortunately it rewatchability is basically zero.  Not sure how part 2 can rescue the mess caused by one.

While watching the visually stunning images, I kept asking, "What is this scene?" The story structure and various character arcs are compartmentalized, with the leads standing around watching a side character fight a villain with no backstory. This movie's connective tissue suffers from the "and then..." syndrome with a lot of "Why did that need to happen?" and "Who the fuck are these people?"

Although visually interesting and having a few nuggets that suggest a greater potential.  The film seems badly edited and most of the story is spent assembling a team of characters with little depth and really do nothing to warrant the effort to recruit them.  There is no time to develop any of the characters, the story feels tedious, and the ending is nonsensical.  If you like science fiction mostly for the eye candy and not the story, it may be worth the watch.

So I quickly put my foot down and locked in.

"ChatGPT, write me a script composed of clich√©s, but first, imagine yourself as a stupidest neural network whose database consists only of descriptions of three movies. Pretend you were told to envision yourself as a novice, struggling scriptwriter."

A movie that was 30% substance 70% VFX. An ensamble reminiscent of Star Wars, Lord of The Rings, and Dune with about half the heart. 

The movie has beautiful environments that weren't explored with the characters being the same. Poor back stories and a rushed premise give a lack luster feeling leaving you with wanting more in a "half satisfied way". 
This movie was hoping to capture hearts through visuals only to flood the screen with them. The plot, villains, and supporting cast were all a copy paste of pre-existing universes just with extra steps. The movie feels like another expensive flop where unhinged, coked up producers wanted to shove something down our throat with the monomer of "Biggest Movie of the Year". When can we get another movie that loves us? When can we get that fluttering feeling similar to that of Harry bidding farewell to his son, Luke saving the galaxy, or Frodo growing old? Where is the sense of a long adventure coming to an end where you crave no more. Where our story telling appetite has been satiated? 

The movie was visually amazing- stunning? No. Thrilling? Also no. But if you're looking for a movie that will make you reach the bottom of the popcorn bucket, get up off your seat and get a refill mid movie, this is it. Startle up for a modern time B movie with a larger budget than it deserved. Trending the flops of 2023 this movie will leave you not wanting more of it. Part 2 in April 2024? Yeah, I'll leave that one in the queue for a while.

I saw a lot of critics say that this film is a Star Wars knock off. While that is true, for example, the introduction explaining what we are about to watch is a 100 percent Star Wars carbon copy. Rebel Moon also plagiarizes other popular blockbuster franchices such as the MCU. Kora was taken in by the Regent and raised as his own after he destroyed her entire village. Have we seen that before in the MCU? Let's remember that Thanos destroyed Gamora's village, but sparred her and raised her as his own. She then turned on him by joining The Guardians. Similarly in Rebel Moon, Kora betrayed the Regent. You see two more instances of this regurgitated in the MCU. Loki turned on the King of Asgard & Captain Marvel fighting against the Kree.

I hated this movie and I really wanted to love it when I saw the trailers. I'm a Synder fan and I loved his Justice League and BVS, but Rebel Moon wasn't good at all.

I didn't love the narrative and think it was shallow and too simple, maybe too much explanation on everything specifically on the recruiting part, the audience is smart than this, we can get when things are not explicit. Overall it doesn't deserve all this hate, as a sci-fi film lover I think we should enjoy having people interested in making movies that imagine fantastic worlds and explore imagination. It could be much better, but I enjoyed watching. It's better when we simply seat down and watch instead of looking for reasons to criticize everything.

I enjoyed it, more style over substance to be honest and I probably wouldn't have seen in the cinema, but it was a very beautiful popcorn flick that entertained me for the better part of the movie. The plot definitely could've been better without major overhauls, but considering this is supposed to set up a triology of sequels I'm more than willing to cut them some slack.

All in all, I'd definitely watch the sequel(s) however I'm not sure this flick has a high rewatch value. Still beter than most Disney Star Wars movies, Rogue One being the exception.

Worldbuilding and art direction felt like a mashup of other sci-fi universes, with little to no originality, one could almost be convinced they were thought up by an AI image generator. Finally, it's all brought together by a story so boring, predictable and lazy that the striking vistas, decent acting, and well done cinematogrophy couldn't stop the yawns.

After watching the trailer, I had high expectations, but honestly, the movie is a 1.5/5. It's the typical film where just 30 minutes into watching, you know who will betray them, who will save everyone, and what the outcome of the whole story will be throughout the film. They make the female protagonist extremely powerful; the secondary characters are almost useless and are not generally "introduced" to you. They touch a bit on the backstory of the main character but nothing beyond that. Throughout the entire movie, the protagonist doesn't even get a scratch; no bullet hits her, and she dodges every blow. It's like she's a god fighting because I can't explain how she manages a 1 vs. 5 alone without getting hurt. Overall, a pretty mediocre movie, another one of those that tried to copy Star Wars but backfired. I don't recommend watching it, but if you want to waste 2 hours of your life, go ahead.

In a nutshell: What if Seven Samurai was playing Star Wars in Firefly's house while wearing a Warhammer 40K outfit, but with no character development?   

The good: 
Visually, its amazing, costuming, props, fight choreography,  lighting, and cinematography are all top notch.

The bad: 
The plot is a paint by numbers "gather the team" which would be fine, if they gave us a reason to care about ANY member of said team.  There's zero character development, unless you'd consider a few, exposition heavy, flashbacks for the main character, development. I'd have listed the cast among the good, since from other work I know them to be talented, but the script here gives them so little to work with, you wouldn't know it. The dialog feels stilted at the best of times and like they're just dumping info on the audience at the worst. Rebel Moon rushes the viewer from big action set piece to big action set piece never stopping to let us get to know a character beyond "look, they can do this cool fighty thing". Worst of all, the big "twist" betrayal is so forced that it's practically telegraphed before the character who does it even joins the group. 

There's supposed to be a "director's cut" to come later, so maaaaaaaybe the character development was left on the cutting room floor, but unless they're adding another full two hours, I highly doubt it.
Great movie, awesome characters. Loved everything about it.

When a movie is so comically bad that you're not sure if it's intentional for comedic effect. I've seen so many books like this with the prevalence of self publishing, where the concept is fun but the writing drags it down by being impossibly bad. I don't know what the budget for this was, but if you're going to spend money making a movie, why not write it well? This was just one uncompelling scene after another, with plot holes and contrived nonsense, some farce of an ‚Äòassembling the crew'‚Ä¶ I mean, it's so generic and formulaic that I'm writing this through the climax of the movie and missing nothing. This movie is a tragedy and it really didn't have to be.

It's like they tried to use a Firefly type vibe to try to cross Lord of the Rings and Star Wars. Sprinkle in some Dune and Warhammer 40k, and there you go... the hot mess that is Rebel Moon: Part 1. They can go ahead and not bother with Part 2.

I give a lot of sci-fi movies the benefit of the doubt, typically saying "great concept, poor execution"; but even the concept here was so convoluted and derivative that even a good execution probably wouldn't have made up for it.

I sat down excited for this movie. It had a lot of hype. That hype fell flat. I watched the entire thing, though I did stop it 3/4 of the way through, when movies, especially of the action variety, are at their most exciting. I opted to go do some random work instead. I then returned to the movie but only to see  how the train wreck ended. Saying it borrows a lot from other sci fi is an understatement. It also borrows from fantasy as well, which just makes the world building muddled at best. The pacing is horrible and too much info is left out leaving you to almost have to do some absurd mad libs in your head. None of the characters seem to mesh together organically either. If I fully had to describe this movie to someone I would tell them that someone filmed a little kid pretending to play Star Wars with his toys. Except for none of the toys are from matching series. Plus all the toys aren't legitimate licensed toys buy stuff you'd get off Wish.  I will probably watch the r rated version when it drops to see if any coherency is added but I doubt it.

Zack Snyders directing is that of a child playing with action figures.

Generic plot, barebone characters, just uninteresting filler to get to the action sequences.
The action sequences themselves are filled with childish "cool" explosions and almost entirely slow-mo.

Entire movie gathers up these "legendary" characters that literally do nothing, say nothing, have zero personality, no crew dynamics or interactions, all for the buildup to this final battle.... that doesn't even happen.

Even the main antagonists and their ship are built up to be this unstoppable force of destruction on paper but I swear even a gentle fart in the wind could have taken everything down.

Waste of 2 hours unless you REALLY love lensflares, in which case you should go watch star trek instead.

In a world characterized by its slow pace, where time meanders like a lazy river, a touch of nonsense adds whimsy to the mundane. Amidst the deliberate crawl of moments, there exists a peculiar charm, a dance with the absurd that keeps life unpredictable. Within this concoction of leisurely strides and whimsical detours, a hidden reservoir of potential quietly waits to be tapped. It's a delicate balance, a nuanced symphony where the unhurried tempo reveals unexpected opportunities, turning the seemingly nonsensical into a canvas of untapped possibilities.

Rebel Moon: Part One is cinematographically stunning but narratively bereft. You are introduced to an (arguably bloated) ensemble of characters for whom you feel next to nothing, because none of their stories are explored properly. And to make matters worse, nearly every scrap of backstory that is successfully purveyed to the viewer is delivered through a series of dreary monologues. The nail in the coffin for Rebel Moon is the story itself, which is not so much a story as it is a series of hastily glued-together sci-fi tropes from other (far more competent) films in the genre. All in all, it is a beautiful and bland appetizer for the remaining installments, and I am not confident many will be interested in the next course.

Don't listen to the so called "professional critics".   I loved this movie and can't wait to see how it all ends.  Wished I could have seen this on the big screen.   You want a big epic sci-fi movie; Zack gave you one!

The Good:
  1)  The story moved along at a good pace.   I never found myself reaching for my phone.
 2)  The visuals and editing were top-notch.
 3)  Action Sequences were well-done
 4)  Sofia Boutella (Kora) is nice to look at and  turns in a fine performance.

The Bad:
  1)  Very derivative.   Not an original idea in the whole movie.  From the overall plot to each scene
  2)  The dialogue is bad.  Really, really bad at times.  
  3)  Outside of Kora, most of the characters are 1-dimensional
       Admiral Atticus Noble is an embarrassing cliched villian. 

Overall, a bubble-gum movie that doesn't require any thinking and goes well with alcohol.

I really, really liked this. Intentionally watched it before reading reviews. Obviously there are recognisable themes in the story (a journey, an overarching peril, a moppet, a traitor, a disgraced but genius general, a brooding female heroine etc. etc) - and yet it is a swashbuckling, exciting epic. The cast is broad, diverse and visually stunning - there is chemistry between the leads - the heroes and the villains are credible - and the core peril (an empire devouring itself) is a worthy platform. I would give it 5/5, but we still need part 2!!!

Personally I believe this movie to be a great sci-fi action movie. Although many see a substantial amount of problem with the movie. Let's discuss. First off the intro to this movie is slow and the grabbing of sand to smell is off putting to put the least. Not a great start. Although many of the fight scenes are amazingly choreographed and the visual effects make a spectacle of a movie, this is not enough to carry a movie alone. The story telling is a tough subject, many thematic choices and the fact this is a two part story limit the first film to as set up for the second. Meeting characters, history's , so on. Which I didn't see as much a problem. Biggest concern being the lack of use of many of these characters in the "unexpected" final fight scene. I wanted to see the farmer fight in the fields, and the robot was barely in the film. Although I chalk most of this up as movie prep for the second film. Overall I genuinely enjoyed this film and would recommend (when the second releases). It's half a story, and I'm treating it as such. It's like stopping a movie half way through, it's unsatisfying ultimately. I'm excited for the rest.
This movie was a jumble of several trailers for other movies I'd definitely see, but all completely disconnected from each other.

There could be a good movie in here, If Zack had handed over character development to a decent director rather than just info dumps every five minutes, there is no character development and barely any character Interaction, which makes them hollow, merely vessels to get from one pointless set piece to another, I mean what was the point of the bird scene, or the spider entity scene, its just action for the sake action.
So glad the critics are getting slammed. No.1 in over 60 countries. Loved it, can't wait for part 2.

It grew on me more with the second viewing. Looking forward to Part 2.

Yes, this is indeed a mash up of different genres and prior story lines from other movies and plots. However telling them and matching in one new story would be a daunting task but I think achieved in this movie.

The bad; poor character development, bad storytelling, derivate plot, and loads of cliches.  It is almost a B movie; with cartoonishly evil villains, a character that stays shirtless and oiled the entire movie, and griffins.

The hero's journey is a age old tale. This movie is a good hero's journey tale in the spirit of many others. It isn't deep, but I'm really interested in the characters backstories. It's a good yarn that looks beautiful.

This is sci-fi for entertaining those of us blessed with a level of suspension of disbelief that is not weak kneed at the sight of a sounds and sights that have been seen before. 

Kora is good. Moody. Terrifying to those who are her enemy.

Farmers who just want to dig in the earth and grow food. What more humble and honorable people need defended against the merciless "motherland" in other movies? 

You want entertained? Enjoy the movie. You want to feel like you are reliving your first ever glimpse of some childhood hero and villain, grow up.

I was so hopeful about seeing elements from other works I enjoyed (Warhammer, Star Wars, Dune, etc.) but I left seeing nothing but an unorganized uninspired mess of the elements with no clear passion. I'm hopeful the second part will prove me wrong but so far, I'm not impressed.

Loud, boring, pointless, and awkward, Rebel Moon wears many grand inspirations on its sleeve (from Star Wars, to Seven Samurai, to Warhammer 40K, to Princess of Mars, and beyond), and yet somehow pulls all the wrong lessons from those sources. The end result is a painful dull, self-indulgent slog that occasionally flirts with some genuinely good ideas only to squander them. Unfortunately, this movie is simply not worth anyone's time.

Have you ever read Steven Eriksson's Malazan Book of the Fallen book-series? It's an epic high-fantasy series well worth the read, but it's always been kinda love/hate due to its complexity and unwillingness to hold the reader by his/her hand. The story told in the series takes place in a world with hundreds of thousands of years of history and context and, for lack of a better metaphor, basically throws the reader into the deep end of the pool to sink or swim. Those of us that learned to swim learned to love the books. The ones who drowned not so much.

The books work, in part, because they build and present strong and memorable characters that can drive the story and keep it coherent when the context is missing. This takes time, effort and a clever pen but Eriksson lives up to the challenge and the series is well hailed as one of the great ones.

This movie made me think of Eriksson. This, I think, is how a movie would look if someone decided to make an Eriksson-inspired film with deep lore and lots of complexity and context but forgot about the part where they also needed strong and believable characters to drive the story forwards. Because they most assuredly did. Forget about the need for believable characters, that is.

Don't get me wrong, the characters are strong. Any and all of ‚Äòem seems capable of taking out an entire platoon of soldiers at any given time, at least until the plot-armour weakens. That, sadly, does not mean that the characters are believable or able to carry the films lacking scrip or pacing. Because the movie is sadly underwritten in this regard. The scrips consist of people talking ‚Äì at ‚Äì each other, often in an unintended parodically manner, not people talking ‚Äì to- each other in any meaningful way. And the pacing is not just lacking, its plain gone. Often we are forced to witness a more-or-less random scene where people - who have just met and doesn't know each other ‚Äì tell of the most intimate things in order to either establish some sort of tragic background or to make us believe that this is a sort of bonding moment between the characters. To say that it's unbelievable is an understatement.

In sum we are left with a bunch of stereotypical archetypes ‚Äì an assassin, a rebel, a misunderstood and (most likely) unfairly judged traitor, the mandatory actual traitor, the tragic general, a prince and a few others I can remember just now. They are all honourable, have a stereotypical trait or two and are willing to take up the fight with the evil overlords who conveniently dress, talks and acts like nazis, random violence and torture included, so that the storyline can soldier on. This is not the way to build or present your characters, this is not the way to tell a complex story (or at least a simple story in a complex context). This is ‚Äì simply ‚Äì not good enough. 

The visuals are, for the most part, pretty good. There are some good action scenes here and there. The movie, overall, is mediocre but OK enough for the first hour and a half. But the last hour takes it into the land of the unintended and unwillingly funny and not in a good way.

Firstly, I do think this was a promising story, I thought Boutella was great as Kora and most of the special effects were clean and looked great!

However, I think this film fell into the trap of following the Sci Fi epic cliches (evil faction trying to take over the universe but being stopped by a unlikely band of rebels against the odds‚Ä¶ sound familiar?) and films that do that are never going to live up to Star Wars which is why they need to be a Sci Fi epic in their own right rather than leaning too heavily on these influences. Even down to naming one of the main warships of the Motherworld the ‚ÄòImperium Dreadnought', let's just say the movie wasn't the most original.

I also feel the story was thin and slightly rushed and dialogue a little disjointed at times. Plus I'd like to have seen a bit more character development as well as background, we're thrown into this ‚Äòepic' space story with a 2 minutes briefing of the history of this universe and absolutely no information on these characters when we meet them (who they are, where they come from, what their story is). The only character you could say developed and we found a little about was Kora and the most promising character was one we see the least of (Jimmy). Unless you class Ed Skrein's Atticus giving a 10 second description of why each character hates the Motherworld as background. Things did feel a little frantic. On top of that occasionally some of the visuals were uneasy on the eye and Hunham's accent‚Ä¶ I truly hope his character is dead so I don't have to hear his accent again in any upcoming Rebel Moon media. 

That being said it wasn't all bad and I am invested in seeing where the saga leads us and look forward to the sequel with anticipation. The action sequences were a positive as they were well choreographed and the majority of acting and special effects were enjoyable as well. I do want to see more of Kora and see where her story arc goes plus how the Motherworld reacts to the ending of Part 1. Despite the shortcomings there is something about the film pulling me back in for more. 

I perhaps was expecting a bit more of the wow factor and originality from the team behind the film and the budget behind them, they're not exactly amateurs! Room for improvement but if you are a lover of Sci-Fi and have a couple of hours free it's worth a watch.

From space vikings, to space nazis, followed by space irish and space mexicans, and the space indian.. then the space Scotsman comes along..  and they find the space jamaican and they go from space Finland to space mexico..   Zero originality.  You'd swear it was max Payne at times, the way they liberally apply bullet time.  They overdo the bullet time scenes.  It makes you wanna vomit.. they slow everything down to try to make miniscule actions seem breathtaking.. and some scenes drag on for like 10 minutes and add nothing to the story.  You literally wishing you could take the time you wasted watching it back.  All the hype for this trash?  Pass, please.  You'll thank me.
I don't know why everyone is comparing this to star wars this is the best 40k movie we have gotten so far.

If you prefer your movie to be entirely in slow motion while casting quality actors in wooden roles and not allowing anyone to higher a proper writer then this movie will probably be fine. It's like poor food that wasn't even seasoned but then someone painted to look really pretty. He makes enjoyable movies when someone else writes them for him.

The large number of negative reviews meant that I approached this film with low expectations. But it's a good film with great action scenes and special effects. I'm looking forward the part two and hope that they do more films and tv shows in this Universe.
Enjoyed the escape from reality
Writing is so insanely bad

Some of the visuals were cool. The movie feels like a D&D session run by a 10 year old kid running for the first time, without a clear story in mind but just grabbing scenes / encounters that he or she thought were cool from the different movies he or she has seen. There was NO character development, no reason to CARE about any of the characters, and nothing interesting happening in the story. The movie should have a warning in the opening credits NOT to create a drinking game every time there is slow motion since that will certainly result in death by alcohol poisoning. The villains in any Scooby Doo episode have far more depth and far more realistic motivations than the Emp... Impe... errr, "Motherworld" space baddies. This was bad. The only reason why I would give Rebel Moon an edge over awful Last Jedi is that at least Rebel Moon wasn't urinating on a franchise that I actually cared about. This movie was not good.

There are ingredients for an interesting story. This isn't it. The pros are mostly good visual effects and a good performance by Ed Skrein as the main villain. Unfortunately the script is more tell than show, and the story is little more than a retelling of Seven Samurai in a blended Star Wars and Warhammer skin, with paper thin characters, most of whom are entirely forgettable. I'm not sure the promised extended version in the future can save this, and it's unfortunate that it's even necessary for it carry that burden.
I think it is one of the better films I have seen in 2023 - don‚Äôt agree with the score critics are giving - very satisfying Sci-Fi . Would have been a great Star Wars Film .
Decent film, drags on a bit, a mix of the magnificent 7 and Star Wars.

I wanted to like this movie but the opening scene CGI was on par with the painted backdrops of 70's era sci-fi series...and it was down hill from there.  Not a single original concept to be found ensures you'll be 5 steps ahead of this story from start to finish.  More painful exposition than a Star Wars prequel.  Textbook example of how important good writing is....and what happens when it isn't. Oh and the title should have been Vikings vs. Nazi's in Space.
It's so bad. Looks like bad trip. Star Wars +  Suicide Squad and too much slow motion.
Ridiculous! I've managed only about 30 minutes torturing myself with that... Awful.

That it does it quite well comes as a pleasant surprise. Fast paced, great heroine and baddie to unite against, excellent visuals all made for a real treat. Looking forward to the next!

Nice polish but that's all. Stiff, wooden dialogue. NO character development, no sense of danger, urgency, direction or plot. It all seem to have been made on the same parking lot. In one word: Terrible.

It's an intergalactic re-make  of 7 Samurai/The Magnificent 7, but it works. It's good escapism which is sorely missed  right now in Hollywood. My only complaint is that Zack takes too long introducing the characters and their is too much exposition. Visually, the fight scenes are stunning. It's better than all of the recent Star Wars movies except Force Awakens and Rogue One!

I think the movie is awesome.  It was filmed like an art house, or graphic novel movie, somewhat (no expert, but that is what it seems to me), so it looks and feels a little different than what I was expecting.  However, once I understood that, I was completely onboard.  It draws on the Seven Samurai, which might be the only (little) let down.  Not that the story isn't good, but it has been done (a lot).  So, you know where it is going.  Over all, I think its a good watch and I really enjoyed it.  Looking forward to the next one.

I understand this is a part one, but it spends the majority of it's runtime assembling its cast of characters in the most basic way. Then, they barely interact or speak. It gives us nothing for us to care about this group. The little we learn about them is in the form of a one sentence description delivered by the villain near the end. All the while lacking in any kind of originality. 

The lead gets the most backstory told in flashbacks which sounds like a much more interesting story. Truthfully, most of the characters seem to have their more interesting stories already behind them. 

There are some nice visuals here and there, but it also looks ugly at times too. There's a good action sequence early and that's where the film peaked for me. The third act is a pretty standard shootout. It's fine for a film to have a small scale conflict, but there was so little going on throughout the movie that it felt like nothing happened at all. 

Ultimately we got a derivative movie, nothing-characters, thin plot, inconsistent visuals, and an unsatisfying end. Very disappointing.

There's nothing new to see here. There are space vikings, space samurai, and space nazis and a group of them form a league in a quest for justice. There's plenty of CGI and slow motion shots but the story is seemingly written by an AI that understands all the familiar tropes but isn't interested in any of the details.

This movie is not an original concept and borrows heavily from multiple stories you've already seen, but that doesn't mean it lacks entertainment.  The story is compelling and the visuals are top notch.  Well worth a watch, and I'm looking forward to more.

Maybe among the worst of 2023 and one of the most difficult films in recent years, to fully watch till the end.

- Story really bland and slow-paced. Maybe with part 2 some parts make more sense but as a movie alone - no.

- Visuals, maybe the worst part of this one. The awful use of DoF and ridiculous amount of slow-mo usage makes some scenes look very bad. The film itself has a grim, unappealing look with some nice scenes.

I can't recommend this movie to anyone - it felt like a waste of time.

Meh, wasn't bad, wasn't amazing.   If you are looking to be entertained for a couple hours, it's not a bad choice.  But don't expect a new incredible epic either.

The good:
Effects and visual quality were great, top notch
Cast is solid and interesting
Fight/action choreography is decent

The meh:
Starts a bit slow, gets a bit better though
Characters are somewhat interesting but not well developed (yet)
Not much interplay between characters, they are just existing next to each other
Acting is ok
Unlike Star Wars, Avengers or even LOTR, little humor.   That can be good or bad depending on what you are looking for (I'm ok with it).

The bad:
Completely cliche, plot is nothing new or groundbreaking
Suspend your disbelief...plot holes abound

The above two points are my only major criticisms...but they are HUGE.   The plot is predictable, totally unrealistic (even for a space scifi fantasy movie).   How are these individuals supposed to fight a huge empire and space ships...with their swords and a pistol?

If the writing/plot were greatly improved, it would very cool.  But for now, it's kinda just ok.   Not a waste of time if you like action and sci-fi, but don't expect an epic.   I'd compare it to feature length "The Expanse" with better effects and choreography but less interesting and more cliche' plot.

It's like someone had asked chatGPT to write a script for "the magnificent seven in space". To say that it is derivative would be a kindness. It's more like a smorgasbord of lines and scenes plagiarized from other Sci-fi movies. The acting is wooden, and the script is clunky - it's like a bad Star Wars fan fic. The writing makes George Lucas seem as sophisticated and witty as Oscar Wilde. Also, the director loves lens flare even more than JJ Abrams. An absolute stinker.

At its heart, Rebel Moon is a fun ride. Who doesn't love the gathering of fallen heroes in pursuit of a lost cause and a chance at redemption? It does borrow heavily from Star Wars, Warhammer 40k and the Seven Samurai. It's visually stunning and has a good pace. It sets up a part 2 to be VERY interesting. I encourage all scifi geeks to take a look and judge it for yourself.

A full lack of imagination on display. I am surprised the writer is not being sued for poor plagiarism. Dune, Star Wars, and the Magnificent Seven fans are vommitting in their mouths a little. A big waste of time and money. Skip it!!

La pel√≠cula empieza siendo un intento de one frame one picture haciendo parecer todo tan "cinematogr√°fico" sin serlo realmente, en algunas escenas se desenfocan ciertas partes de la pantalla de manera inexplicable, los personajes solo aparecen si raz√≥n aparente, contexto ni prop√≥sito de ser, que un pelicula tenga presupuesto no es sin√≥nimo de que se" vea bien " Godzilla minus one es el ejemplo, es una pel√≠cula exclusiva para los fans de Zack lo cual no est√° mal pero no la hace buena, sino todo lo contrario, el slow motion peor implementado de todas sus pel√≠culas, al igual que su peor cinematogr√°fia, su mayor error es querer ser 300 cuando no lo es, y tener un gui√≥n que parece sacado de una historia que me creaba yo mientras jugaba con mis legos, 2/10

I saw someone describe this as an RPG when you skip all the dialogue options and I feel like that's about the best description there could be. There's no character development, hell there's not really even any characters. They hired some actors to immediately join the party without any personality or reason to care about them. Absolutely no depth at all. The big betrayal doesn't matter because we haven't gotten to know the characters enough for it to matter. There's no chemistry between the characters so there's no emotion to it.  The party is assembled on a bunch of planets we're given no information about or reason to care about in a universe that short of some generic exposition we don't have any reason to care about.  The action was poorly choreographed nonsense to the point the tiny steps people were taking "running" and awkward body posture when they knew things are going to be slowed down just looked ridiculous.  The fights didn't flow and were the worst "bad guy stands around and waits their turn" possible.  The story isn't just rushed it's fractured and disjointed. Things just happen without any reason for them.  I have no idea how this has as high rating as it does because this film is trash.

It's a really bad version of A Bug's Life crossed with Serenity, Star Wars, Dune and Battle Beyond The Stars with a sprinkling of The Magnificent Seven. The slow mo gets boring very quickly, the dialogue is terrible, the story is derivative, there is zero humour. It takes itself so seriously that it's painful to watch all the way through. It's a series of really cool set pieces that look great in a trailer. I really wanted this to be good. It isn't.

Exposition intercut with low stakes action. A good looking assortment of characters you don't care about, or even like, are thrust between unconnected action scenes with little drama.

Also the bringing together of characters is slow. My major issue though is that when it finally started to get going and you settle in, it ends and as of writing this, we have about five months until the next part comes out. And by then it won't have the same impact. But I would like to feel that a new "thing" is being created here. I hope that this goes on to having its own universe with more depth to it, being learned. I won't spoil the story. I just wanted to give a feel for it. But definitely watch it. I look forward to watching it again around when the next part comes out

In the running for worst movie of the decade. *spoilers*
Consistently nonsensical plot. Characters introduced early then forgotten until the end of the film. Recruit a general, he's absent from all the planning, recruit rebels, immediately murdered. See informant captured, tell no on that their covers been blown.
Writing is equally amateurish. 20% of the film is poorly written monologues from the protagonist, "she was named Issa after an ancient Queen, Issa the life giver. It was said she could give life". Or a long monologue telling us about how she was "adopted" and raised to be a military officer. followed by "at the age of 18 I was made an officer and given a command" OBVIOUSLY, WE JUST WATCHED THAT HAPPEN OVER THE ENTIRE MONOLOGUE, WHY ARE YOU ALSO TELLING ME THIS????.
The whole film is scenes and tropes lifted from other media and pasted into Rebel Moon. 40k fake Latin and fancy uniforms, bad Mos Eisley Cantina ripoff, Jason Mimosa inspired Gryphon taming scene from Harry potter, Blades edge Mts ripped from Wow Burning Crusade.
Barf.

A compelling setting with great visuals squandered by a cast of paper-thin characters and a soulless story. This movie attempts the classic Seven Samurai formula but fails to create compelling and likable characters. The film casts character development and plot cohesion aside to squeeze in as much action as possible, which might be a plus for some.

If you are looking for a mindless action film that allows you to turn your brain off and marvel at the gorgeous setpieces and action sequences, you will enjoy this film. If you are looking for a compelling narrative with a cast of lovable characters, you would be better off searching elsewhere.

You know, I'm a fan of many movies and many directors, but most of all I'm a fan of good stories and good characters.  This has both.  Sure, there are some issues with battle scene slow motion (which personally I think can detract from the chaos and intensity of battle) but it's a minor niggle if the story works. It's also refreshing to have a story not beset by a big studio "message" or pandering to be relevant in today's society and just being a story.  It's a traditional story about empire stomping on those that it claims to protect, the things that real world rebellions have been caused by, but it's an enjoyable ride along with a band of characters and protagonists that left me wanting to see a) the next chapter and b), the extended r-rated version.

Visually impressive, and generally entertaining. There was potential for this movie to be one of the best science fiction movies in a long time. It started strong, and had compelling characters, but then it all started to feel rushed. New characters were introduced like we already knew their backstory--and were immediately trusted by the protagonists without question. There is an overwhelming Star Wars theme throughout--from the villain emerging from near death, to bar scenes, and the hero rising from a modest farming community. What saves this movie is the visuals, action sequences, and there is nothing that is noticeably terrible, like dialogue, or massive plot holes. It definitely would have benefited from pacing, character development, and a longer runtime. They should made this into a limited series.

An world and story full of potential, but intrigue is lost when the it started to feel formulaic. The start of the film had me interested in the world and Kora, the main character. But as she goes on a venture to recruit an army, it turns into a predictable structure of "land on planet, observe a character overcome a great feat, and have them join the crew for no convincing reason." This would have been a better format if done as a series with 8-10 episodes. If each episode could have been spent on a planet, exploring the lore, culture, races, and laws of that world and making us care about the character that's eventually recruited, it would have been way more impactful by the end of the season. But rather, when the big fight happens at the end of the film, I had little to no investment into the characters (at times I couldn't even recall their names), therefore, I have no reason to care who lives or dies. I just simply watched it feeling next to nothing.
It had good graphics, but while the battle scenes look nice, they cut into slow motion so often and at times that felt unneeded, that it made the battles feel too long. It also fell into the same trap that we see in action movies, where no one, despite being trained soldiers, can aim their guns properly, or hit their targets if their lives depended on it (and yes, their lives DID depend on it.) Of course, our main character and her crew had exceedingly good luck with their aim. :S
Thankfully, the ending of the film left me intrigued and wanting to tune in for Part 2. If only the middle of the film was as strong as the start and end, it would be near perfect. Unfortunately, the thought of sitting through this film a second time is not a thought I'll be having anytime soon.

I dont understand all the hate. I think it was very good. It has one job: to tell an entertaining story. It accomplished this job and fairly well. It truly did. The acting was fabulous. The sets were very well done. Production value was high. Bonus: it was also free. Yes, the story is not particularly original, but what story is?  The good versus evil plot is an ancient one retold many times. Kudos not codemnation are in order. If you notice it was the critics who rated it so low. The audience seems to rate it at almost a 70%.  I am always suspicious of those who do not  create anything, yet judge those who do with vitriol. SMH.

Is it cheesy? Definitely. Some parts are a little rough, and there's definitely a requirement for suspension of disbelief. Soooo many storylines that felt shorter than they could've been, but I wanted more. Special effects were very, very fun. Thoroughly enjoyable. Looking forward to part 2.

Had potential.  Visually it's beautiful, but it lacks depth. The characters are 2d...really don't like them. They lack almost any redeemable qualities.  And really annoyed at them waiting to have the "rated R" version...so stupid...

Some characters don't really get fleshed out enough, and the pacing can be a little jumpy at times, but Rebel Moon builds an incredible universe, with complex motivations for its core cast, satisfying action sequences and does a good job of resolving its own conflict while building towards Part 2. Very enjoyable watch.

Very paint by numbers story that cant decide if it wants to be Star Wars or Dune.  Foreshadowing is non existant and a quick speech is all it takes to get people to join her crew. There were story elements I recognised for sure, it's a sci-fi hero movie with a pretty big nod to Seven Samurai/Magnificent Seven, and various other franchises... but so what.
The FX were well done, the fight scenes had a Riddick vibe (the whole slo-mo thing)... the score was epic, if a bit light on themes.... some of the dialog was a bit "obvious".
But as a world builder, leaving questions (as it should)... pretty good.
So, in the grander scheme of things, did I enjoy it? Yes
Am I looking forward to the next part, did I finish this one wanting to see more? ... 100% yes.
Our family loved it! We can't wait for part 2!

Really deserves 4 stars, but people seem to get off on hating this movie, so tried to counter that with a 5 star. It's enjoyable, looks pretty, and makes me want to see Part II. It's not groundbreaking, but it doesn't need to be. Sometimes it's ok for a movie to just be enjoyable.

The movie is long, with very little character development. While visually pretty at times, they don't stay in any one place long enough for you to really explore the area. The dialogue is laughable, with one scene in particular the main character is trying to convince another person to join her team and the things she says are so bad I began laughing out loud as she spoke the lines. It is a straight up remake of the seven samurai, I'm not sure where the articles claiming it's an original story get that idea from... in seven samurai, you have japanese farmers searching for samurai to defend their village from raiders stealing their rice... in Rebel Moon, you have... space farmers.... searching for space warriors.... to defend their village from an empirial admiral stealing their wheat....

What did I just watch. Hollywood directors need to go train in Japan and learn how to create good films again. The plot was boring and predictable. The acting was sub par. They really wasted the talent they had. And the main character was just horrible, just about everyone else in the film was more believable than her and had a better story arc. Very poorly executed project.

This movie was kind of a mess. The plot was paper thin which I mean is fine for a B sci fi flick but it was so choppy. From the outset it didn't flow at all. We start on a farm where we have our hero and possibly two "unlikely allies" that never show up again for whatever reason but were made to seem important (yes I'm aware there's more parts but at least make it make sense). The giant exposition dumps from our main heroin were bad. Go into the "recruitment phase" for this little adventure and it just felt like it just jumped from one planet to the next without truly fleshing out any of the characters for real. So you didn't actually care why they were joining this crew. The abilities they had to aid in this "rebellion" didn't really make any sense. We had a farmer, a grifter, a wannabe anime female assassin type, a retired drunken general, and some random barbarian types because why not. If I missed anyone else it was because they were just THAT forgettable. ALL of the fight sequences save for one in the bar were awful (typical stormtrooper fodder minus the fun). The sad part is I found the background characters that had like one scene infinitely more interesting than the main cast. A lot of slow mo when it wasn't necessary. In fact in the final fight the slow motion made this big "hero moment " of one of the characters look like he was straight out of Team America: World police. That actually got a laugh out of me. TLDR: It was a mess, the characters sucked and if I didn't know that it was taking itself seriously I would have thought it was a parody.

I've never written a movie review.  I had thought about writing a movie and now I think I definitely can. Just do a bunch of drugs, watch as much anime,fantasy and sci-fi as possible and maybe not sleep. You will have rebel moon. Characters from gladiator to mad max fury road. Toss in a few light sabers, spider people and hobbits(orcs wtv tf) also. I cannot believe this movie was produced without any production company or studio suing the producers or whomever.  I have seen it once and do not plan to ever again. While Rebel Moon borrows from a lot of Sci-Fi tropes, it really failed to deliver a compelling and riveting story. Visually, this movie is a wonder to see and it has that Warhammer 40k aesthetics to it. However the execution of the story ruins it by giving us characters with no personalities and makes us believe that they would easily band together with very little effort. It is unfortunate that this movie will heavily rely on the next chapter in order for it to be considered whole. Most movie series that are considered to be top tier have held their own with each movie. Each movie should have its own separate arc that will culminate at the conclusion, sadly for this movie, it will rely on the next installment (Scargiver) for it to be considered digestible. 

The good: visually amazing and I really love the concept

There is no denying that the film is derivative, but I disagree with reviewers who say it is only derivative of Star Wars, Dune, or other large Sci-Fi franchises. I think it is mostly derivative of samurai films and retellings of the Seven Samurai/Magnificent Seven, set in space. If you have liked many of the retellings of that classic story,  you may enjoy this. The visuals are stunning, and although the dialogue is a little wooden, it certainly isn't more wooden than George Lucas' dialogue. I didn't particularly care for the Spirit: Stallion of the Cimarron "noble savage" element and really wish they could have given the actor a shirt, but overall I liked the film and will watch the second half.

I am excited to see where the sequels take us. I have my ticket and some popcorn at the ready!

This movie has more in common with his 2002 Dawn of the Dead, in that this movie just didn't die. You think it's over, but no, it keeps going. Not that the visuals weren't unimpressive, they were. However the dialogue, the story, its a 2 hour movie with 90 mins of exposition. Were they ripping off Star Trek? Star Wars? Harry Potter? Villains too evil to possibly exist, is the main bad guy a space Nazi or a space peaky blinder? Too many locations, a cat with a beak stuck on it, terrible cgi, awful unlovable characters, predictable 'twists'
Great film. Little predictable, but very entertaining!

Yes. There's plot holes, character development issues, and story beats that...seem to go nowhere. But I still REALLY enjoyed the film. Because for all of these negatives, it also did SO MUCH right. It gave us a rich, unique universe ripe for exploration. A well crafted, mysterious, competent main character that I want to keep following. Audio and Visuals that a distinctly their own, despite how many tropes and ideas were borrowed from other famous Sci-Fi stories like Dune and The Chronicles of Riddick. Everyone is quick to say this film rips off Star Wars, while seeming to forget that Star Wars was HEAVILY inspired by Flash Gordon and Dune.

I admired the objectively good set design, The stupendous score, And the sense of curiosity about where the story is going to go. And ya know what...I think the audience score on rotten tomatoes is right. 70% is COMPLETELY fair. This movie is without a doubt a 7/10. A flawed, yet intriguing first entry into a new franchise that has room to blossom into something that could last for years to come, or crumble under the weight of it's own talented, yet at times pretentious creator.

Well, when watching it's quite easy to see right off the bat why so many people are being critical of this film. It's definitely not without its flaws, and there are several. However from what I've heard, there's to be an ‚ÄòR rated' Director's Cut being released next spring, purportedly featuring an additional hour or so of extra content that's meant to fill in the majority of gaps in the character development and storyline issues that people keep complaining about.
 
I agree with many on this point, that although it's technically a movie with 2+ hour runtime, it does feel seemingly rushed through, but on the upside, I thought the pacing moved along pretty swiftly throughout, aka meaning, I didn't find myself at all getting bored. Those 2+ hours blew by, and admittedly by the time the credits were rolling, I was left feeling the desire to see more. Which isn't so bad since Part II is supposedly being released soon-ish.

So me personally, I'm eager to watch the directors cut despite an estimated runtime of 3.5 hours. I believe the upcoming extended release version will potentially add on another 1/2 star to my initial rating due to it providing a sense of completeness to whatever seemed lacking from the first edit. 

In summary, was this the absolute best sci-fi flick of the year that rivals the likes of the monolithic galaxies portrayed in Star Wars? Oh, HELL to the NO‚Ä¶but was it something that's adequately entertaining, dazzling to eyes and a fairly decent way to spend an evening passing some time? Yes. Yes, I believe it is.

Probably the worst movie my son and I have seen in the past few years. Honestly it's so awful it's to the point of laughter bad. It's so bad that we turned Rebel Moon on (for the third time, can't watch something this awful in one sitting) just to get some laughs in. Whoa! Make sure you watch this one on trash pickup day because this movie hot garbage! Since it is visually stunning, I moved it from 1-star to 2-stars. But it honestly has nothing else going for it other than beautiful set pieces. After spending 2+ hours with these characters, I can honestly say you will know them as well at the beginning of the movie as you do at the end. The character development is almost non-existent, and then we are asked to care when certain characters are killed -- but there is 0 emotional connection and the story is so wide-ranging you would need to make it a series to do it justice. 

Going from place to place to collect a rag-tag group of fighters for an upcoming battle, our heroine encounters one person after another who wants no part of it -- only to have their mind changed by a three-sentence speech from our protagonist. Umm...I don't think so. This on top of being introduced to a couple of characters early on that are made to feel like they will be integral to the plotline, only to have them completely disappear after the first 10 minutes.
good movie...  I would definitely watch a sequel.  It has a good overall story and I look forward to seeing the story continue.
Wasn't bad, but wasn't good either. The story has lots of holes in it, character development is janky, but it passed the time.
Boring.  Lame Star Wars ripoff.  I fell asleep multiple times.
Amazing. I just think these critics have trouble following a complex sci-fi story
For me its decent not Zack's best nor his worst I will say go ahead and release the Director's cut, its not a terrible movie imo but it does feel like something missing.

This is a good movie.  Many have stated it is derivative of Star Wars and The Magnificent Seven.  So what? The Magnificent Seven was remake of the Seven Samurai.  I like the visuals and the action scenes.

Sure,  anyone can guess the plot line.  Sit back with a beer or glass of wine and enjoy the ride.  Good mind candy.

From the first scene on, the visuals, characterisation and acting combine into something that feels, looks and sounds like a bad case of CGI fanfic. And so it turns to be. On the edge of being unwatchable, you just feel strung along in a story that seems to continuously grouse: this is what Star Wars should be. And that is before someone thought it was a good idea to resurrect General Bison.

I loved the cinematic visual effects, but as a first part to a 2 part story I feel that there was missing a deeper story of every characters.

Not sure why anyone's calling this "visually dazzling." The first 30 minutes on the farm planet (Middle Earth Tattooine) have a few fun looking aliens and some very Lord of the Rings inspired set dressing. Even though everyone seems to have dressed at the local Gap Outlet.

After the first 30 minutes, everything is underlit, out of focus, with enough lens flare to choke JJ Abrams. Every space location is a murky, featureless unpopulated void. Every ship is an underdetailed conglomeration of boxy shapes. 

This is dull and derivative from start to finish, its limited imagination seemingly butting against a limited budget. Half of the effects look good, half look like they were rendered in 2003. 

If you really want an incomprehensible, overstuffed sci-fi epic with terrible dialog but pretty visuals, just watch Jupiter Ascending. It's better. Which is saying something.
Amazing! Forget the critic fanboys! Get your popcorn out this is a good one!

I didn't care about a single character not one

I just saw this move and had some doubts. The reviews are not great. But I was pleasantly surprised. If you don't compare it to anything and just take it at face value it's not a bad movie. In today's world you can watch a different movie at the push of a button, so for a movie to hold my attention for 2 hours that, to me, is a good move.

The professional critics giving this movie a 25% are the worst of Internet trolls. This is a very entertaining epic scale sci-fi movie. Sure there could be a little more character development, or a little less homage to movies like The seven samurai, but at the end of the day all these stories have been told. You won't regret watching this unless you're a real weenie.
It has the best of the Director visually; the story is serious, and creates enough drama and the story line as the first act of several future chapters.

A big budget knockoff of a low budget knockoff.  Basically, this is a knockoff of "Battle Beyond the Stars", the 1980 Roger Corman film which was, in itself, a knockoff of both "Star Wars" and "The Magnificent Seven", set in space. There was nothing new here that hadn't been already done over 40 years ago.  Very disappointed in Zack as this was a very lazy attempt to spit shine an old doorknob.  I pray that part 2 as well as the directors cuts add some extra polish to this film, otherwise it was just an over-hyped and very expensive exercise in lazy story-telling.
Definitely was a much needed Sci-fi action, adventure film. Worth the wait. The story, film graphics, actors/actresses were awesome. What we need now is either Part 2 and/or the uncut versions!
I dont know what the critics are smoking. I really enjoyed this and plan to watch again.

This is an example of forced filmmaking. The story is not compelling, nor are the characters believable. The acting consists primarily of reading monologues or staring angrily at the camera. There is nothing memorable about the music, scenery or the vehicle design. "Move along. This is not the film you are looking for. "
Some scenes are just a joke. Lot of marketing, lack of raw material. Will not be watching part 2
Masterpiece of modern SF.

OK. Sp you can see almost from the beginning it was meant to be a star wars movie. But it's sufficiently reworked to be something different. Borrows not just from SW but Warhammer Seven Samurai Dune & others.
Took its time to spell out the story and while characters are solid some could have done with a bit more polishing. It's interesting enough to keep you watching to the end & I have a feeling pt2 will even better. 
It's a good film. Way better than anything contained the SW sequels. It concentrates on telling the story which is what is most important. I don't what film the critics watched but it wasn't this one. This is a good film.

This is something else. It is good, maybe nit great but us very entertaining. Visuals in general are great, some CGI does look strange at times when ir comes to characters/creatures. This is the first of three so  it clearly st up characters and story so it's not expected to be action packed though it delivers accordingly. Yeah is not nothing new in terms of Ci-Fi fantasy, I didn't like the element of having a fantasy magical creature but the rest of the concept of a universe more looking like ours gives it a different touch some people might expect more futuristic aspect but that would be a Star Wars/Star Trek thing, it's obvious they wanted ro be far away from that and that is fine.

A really bad remake of Seven Samurai. It's been remade before, but much better. The Magnificent Seven, A Bugs Life, even the low budget Battle Beyond The Stars was better than this. A slow mo action mess of a movie that's full of boring exposition.

The film has zero ideas of its own. The story is based on Akira Kurosawa's masterpiece "The Seven Samurai" or later the western remake "The Magnificent Seven". Then add borrowings from "Star Wars", a pinch of "Dune", a little "Avatar" and stir vigorously. An almost painfully frequent use of slow-motion effects, as if the director wanted to say "we couldn't think of anything, that's why we're making the film so artificially long." Illogical situations, such as a simple farmer who has never left his home planet before, knows how to deactivate the mother world's execution device without ever seeing it. And the end of the first part is so copied from "Star Wars: Revenge of the Sith" that it's embarrassing. If you want to have a nice evening with an exciting film, you should rather go back to one of the originals that "Rebel Moon" was "inspired" by.

He had dialogues with ZERO subtext, all exposition, a useless amount of slowmotion that borders the ridiculous, and characters with ZERO depth, expecially the protagonist. The only good thing is the CGI
Very entertaining tribute Kurosawa 7 Samur√°is versi√≥n. Great visuals.
Another overhyped copy and paste movie, borrow everything from everywhere and hope that something will stick, Steal the plot from seven samurai, mix in a healthy dose of star wars.

Rebel Moon is definitely a good movie. Far from perfect, but nowadays we should get our wins whenever we can.

The story is simple, perhaps a little too simple. And it doesn't dodges the typical cliches seen in this genre of movies. But we can see the potential of this world that Zack Synder has created.

Overall character performances were good and some even very good, unfortunately the performance of the main character Kora (Sophia Boutella) is not amongst them. I had hoped she had grown more as an actress, but it seems clear she will not be growing beyond what she has already shown in the past.
And it's a shame really seeing her character played perhaps by another actress like let's say Emily Blunt, would've really shined and could've perhaps been the creation of quite an important character within the sci-fi genre.
I understand why Sophia Boutella was chosen for this role, her dancing skills really come through in the action scenes. But it's her ability to show deeper levels of emotion that are lacking and for her character that's also a vital part.

Rebel Moon hasn't done anything groundbreaking or revolutionary, but it's still a solid movie. Same as the story might seem too simplistic to some, to others it seems to go over their heads. Some negative critics about it are not only unwarranted but a little petty. As if they were expecting this movie to be what Star Wars or Alien were in their beginning.
When even Star Wars and Alien can't reproduce their winning formula.

Don't go into this movie with too much expectations and will surprise you in a good way. Go into thinking it will be groundbreaking within the genre and you'll obviously be disappointed.
Rebel Moon has potential and it's a good addition to the genre, but it doesn't do anything that can't be expected from a good sci-fi movie. And that's already quite an achievement considering how little in terms of good sci-fi movies we really get.

At least Rebel Moon doesn't promise to shoot for the Moon only to fall in a few meters.

Yes it is very cheesy in places but, I really enjoyed it.  I felt the first half was probably a bit slower than the rest but the ending had a far different pace.  The action sequences were not bad, that acting was good, but man the script is  not so great.  I get the feeling that Part 2 might even things out more.  Just remember the original Star Wars had some terrible reviews and now is regarded as a true classic...
The backstory is pretty long but all the fighting scene all amazing...

There is a reason they say show, not tell. This was all tales of the achievements of characters that we barely get to see come together. Just a linear pageant, with the last participant dying to try and fail at making an emotional impact. I couldn't get past the visual effects and stylisation copied from Warhammer 40K universe.

Of course it's derivative, we knew it was a gritty Star Wars meets  Seven Samurai. But the execution is in general good, the action is fun and the visuals dazzling. The plot manages to do decent world building at a brisk pace, keeping exposition to a minimum necessary, letting its derivative natures fill on the gaps for the audience. This first act is about assembling a team of interesting rogues, giving them a thin, mostly implicit backstory, and setting up the second act: their battle against unsurmountable odds to defend the little guy. The acting is ok, it lacks any memorable performances. The climatic fight scene stretches logic a bit, in true Star Wars style only the good guys have good aim and come out on top after being restrained and surrounded by enemy troops. Still it manages to be fun and exciting.
Storyline weak, characters show little to no charisma, part two has a lot of ground to make up!

After stealing from other movies (Seven Samurai, Star Wars, Prisoner of Azkaban etc), introducing us more and more boring characters with zero personalities and filling the screen with poor, unfinished video game graphics, Rebel Moon dares to end with "End of Part One" text, thinking I'd be interested to watch Part Two.

Visually exciting this movie could be plucked right out of the established Starwars universe. But the story line is hollow and dull leaving you with a sense of sadness and longing for cinema that actually attempted to excite you with new and original ideas. You can easily predict each  plot point as it unfolds like a wet blanket. This is all just copy and paste much the same as the recent Star Wars franchise. As the first part of a trilogy this film attempts to build up anticipation for the subsequent films however I anticipate diminishing viewership for each subsequent part. So much squandered potential.
Not perfect but very beautiful and interesting and I need more exploration

Movie was great, can't wait for Part 2.

Immersive and thrilling, Rebel Moon offers an experience that seamlessly blends futuristic visuals with heart-pounding action sequences. The narrative is simple yet captivating, transporting the audience to new and fascinating worlds. The choreographed action scenes are visually spectacular and serve to drive the plot, keeping the audience on the edge of their seats. From start to finish, the pacing is expertly handled, ensuring an exciting and thoroughly enjoyable journey.
I'm not saying Rebel Moon is better than Star Wars‚Ä¶ OK.  I am. Why?  The gore of battle!  Star Wars is cute in comparison.

I found the plot derivative, the characters superficial, the dialogue inane, and the stereotypes numbing‚Äîall wastes of the actors' and VFX artists' talents. I was very excited when I first saw "Rebel Moon" advertised, but now I just feel sad.

I have no idea how people correlate this to star wars. Why? Because it is set in space? What the heck? Zero semblance.

I watched it with low expectations, I think that worked in its favor, although it's still unsatisfactory. It's a stumbling movie that doesn't quite know how to structure the story it wants to tell, and it simply manages by ellipses and flashbacks inserted inorganically, to try to drive the entire story behind it a little. All the interactions between characters are lost, and in the end, you don't care about them. The best thing that can be said about this movie is that it doesn't make you feel like you've wasted your time, but it doesn't evoke any emotion, you feel nothing once it's over, it just ends. With the announcement of a second part, let's hope it doesn't disappoint us like this.

This was the worst movie I have seen in a long, long time. I can't remember a movie off the top of my head that was as trashy as this. The graphics look like a low budget video game, the acting was shockingly bad, and it's basically like watching a bunch of loosely woven vignettes with o my the barest hint of unifying story. If they cut out the endless, gratuitous slow motion scenes, it would have shaved about thirty minutes off the movie. It is a poor rip-off of Star Wars, and was utterly abysmal. No redeeming qualities. If you value your time, skip it.

It was a good movie. Great cast and action. Sure it has its faults, lots of plot armor for main characters and some inexplicable moments in general but I'd like to see more of this universe. Very much Warhammer 40k meets Star Wars. Awesome designs for ships, armor, weapons and planets. Needs to be fleshed out more but this was a good start, strong female lead, not some damsel in distress. The whole cast needs to be more expressive though, I know now they are trying to be under the radar but it would be better to see them being more active. Backstory would have been a better place to start for the main and some support characters but a fun watch nonetheless and a visual treat. What was the struggle initially? I have a lot of questions but hopefully they can be answered in the future in film/series formats. Comic tie-ins seem lazy to me for exposition, do a book if needed.

Dirt farmers with automatics doors on their homes but no modern tools?  Space Nut Sees (I kid you not) with no discipline. Good movie. My only complaint is that there isn't enough character development. They assemble a team that took little convincing to join their cause and we don't learn a whole lot about them. It otherwise had a good story, nice action sequences, cool world designs, and I enjoyed the show-mo moments. I'm looking forward to part two.
Drama without context, not worth the calories.

Good cast, interesting premise, no expenses spared with CGI and costume design, but by the end of the 2 hour run time it all collapses under the weight of a poor screenplay.  Felt like a film student project that just ripped off existing movies, and tried to cram so many things into two hours at the expense of any character or world building beyond a few lines of cheap exposition.

It started out okay, then started to feel bad and by the end I felt angry at giving up two hours of my life while at the same time I found myself laughing at how bad the last line uttered in the movie was.

I enjoyed reading reviews of people thrashing this movie more than the movie itself at least.

If you took Star Wars, Dune, Avatar, Harry Potter Maze Runner, Hunger Games and just about any sci-fi of the past 60 years and ripped out random tropes mixed with a tired and worn, but tried and true plot of a rebel against an all controlling evil empire you have rebel moon. Visually interesting but marked by clear cgi shortcuts it's worth a watch compared to whatever other unoriginal rehashed drivel is being produced lately.
Fun action, good story, there was a little bit of bad dialogue but overall great movie

Idk what's up with the RT score being 21% from starting off at a 9%. That's kinda insane. I thought this movie was awesome. The story is a classic Seven Samurai/Knights of the round table kind of team up movie to protect the planet Veldt. Kora and Gunnar set off in search of help and it takes off from there. The pacing is a bit off in the middle of the movie and I feel like a lot of the extended cut will show what we missed out on. But the first and third acts are the strongest. The visuals were out of fucking hand. The flashback scene when Kora dives into her past was one of the best and I was just in awe of how this movie looked. Al there were establishing shots that were as epic as some in Lord of the Rings. At times it felt inspired by a Cronenberg movie with the alien and technology infused aliens. Jimmy the robot was also a great character and I can't wait to see what the extended rated R cut will show as well as Part II : The Scargiver. Also not to forget is the sets, costumes, props, vehicles were awesome. Junkie XL's score complimented the movie so well and hit just right when it needed to.. I suggest watching and deciding for yourself but I think it's a good movie with plenty of rewatch-ability.

3/4 of this film was soooo slow and boring! The fight scene in the village, the scene against the spider and the end of the film were the best bits if you could call them that. Lucky that I gave it a two star rating. Adult version of Starwars someone called this....What a joke....Any of the Starwars franchise's is better than this! I wouldn't waste you time or money watching this movie.
Fun, exciting and engaging! Really enjoyed it!
Absolutely Boring. Zero Action. Weak Story.
I love that movie and the slow scenes. I like the action and if you like the action you won't get bored. I really love it.
I thought it was great tbh.  Not as good as Dune, but way better than any Star Wars movie.  I'll be looing forward to part 2 dropping in 2024.
