The movie itself wasn't perfect but it was enjoyable to watch and worth recommending. The characters are interesting and the action scenes were well done. I will say it is the best sci-fi movie I've seen this year.

I feel there was not a single original idea in this sucker punch of a film, so many old earth accents and not a decent bit of dialogue to be heard. It has a hobbit village, a princess, Conan turns up and does nothing. The greatest general of the age is found and spouts a couple of bad speeches and at one point Jar Jar is seen. Even the visuals are stolen. The bad guys and their weapons are straight out of Warhammer 40k and then the awful out of place OTT music score is trying to punch above it's weight. Another case of great trailer shame about the Film.

Wow, we can discuss some of Disney's questionable decisions about Star Wars...  I really wanted to like this film, but thank the maker for whoever at Lucasfilm/Disney passed on this really pedestrian movie.  They made a VERY good decision!  There's very little if anything new in this film, near zero character development.
Every aspect about it is bad, there is no character development, it is a blunt copy of Star Wars, and the dialogue is trash.

Star wars ripoff? Absolutely
 Worth watching? Absolutely. Some of the CGI was a little poor and some of the characters were a bit derivative (pretty standard girl boss lead knocking ppl out with stick figure arms and female Japanese character who uses swords, to name a couple). Character development definitely lacking - for example who the hell is this general and why is he so angry? No idea. But overall it was visually engaging, and had an extremely good villain along with solid action sequences.

I'm excited to see the next in the series

A somewhat middling movie. It took a big shot and I felt it missed the net for the most part. It tries to set up an appealing universe without providing nearly enough context or information. There are a number of characters who just seem to do things not because they make sense but because the script wants them to. 

While visually pretty I feel like there was an over reliance on slow motion effects that took away from the film, among other odd visual choices. The main one that stood out to me involved a fight breaking out after a young girl is threatened with SA where there was a decent amount of unpleasantness surrounding what happens to the girl on screen to then transition to a fight scene involving axes and knives with not a single bit of blood nor wounds in sight. 

Just an odd film that felt like it had certain points on a checklist it had to hit but not much else to it.

Disappointed. Awkward dialogue, poor pacing and cheesy fight sequences. No feel of direction. Mildly entertaining but it's really just another Sci-fi rebellion movie but poorly executed on almost every aspect.

This is a good version of 7 Samurai... in space! It is visually stunning, there was a seed for a great universe we were introduced to is something I can't wait to learn more about, and I am more than interested in seeing how this universe expands as there are more movies, comics, books, and more introduced!

I liked the plot,  storyline and awesome visuals, but the movie lacked character development. I am sure the R rated version will be much better,  with more background on our heroes. Great movie, ignore the critics.

I think the idea of a "critic" has been lost. Surely a "critic" should judge anm movie so the potential audience can make an educated decision on whether to watch a movie based on an expert opinion. But I'm seeing more and more disparity between "audience" scores and "critic" scores.
If the two metrics are so far apart, what is the point in the "critic"? They're obviously completely unaware of what the audience wants and basing their opinion on some other measure of "entertain-ability" 
I'm starting to think that the "critics" are solely looking for arty-farty, deep and meaningful, artistic, socially - real world questioning films which are inherently boring, frustrating and completely missing the objective of cinema... which is to escape the real world for 90 minutes, not to be reminded of life's stuggles and leave the cinema less depressed than when we arrive.

Amazing world creation, visual, VFX and the Seven Samurais vibe was really interesting. Therefore, the directors cut and the sequel should fill the lack of character development of the movie. Aldo, this doesnt prevent the movie from being a very competent and promising iteration. Very well settled up to the sequel

A great film with interesting characters and world. Although similar to other films in the style of big bad comes to small town. Small town seeks help. This kept me tuned in right through and I wanted to find out more about the characters and the world they are in. I loved the art style of the film.. Although alot of reviews complained about the over use of slow motion I felt it suited the style and was used at the right moments to capture the feel. This isn't fast and furious where its action over style and depth. This is about style, depth and visuals. This is a great new film series where hopefully we see more world building.

ZS is good when directly adapting a story (300 & Watchmen) yet still always has issues with pacing his movies. When it comes to world building and making his own stories though, he's really bad. 

This movie for example, took him an hour to flesh out the premise. Took 30 mins to pick up new characters without any character backgrounds or motivations, no chemistry or interactions between characters. Then all of a sudden there's the obvious and predictable betrayal and quick switch to climax. 

Then there's the always dark world. Even when the sun's up the world is still somehow dark. Also don't get me started with his addiction to slow motion which happens every ten seconds and in every flashback when there's absolutely no need for it.

Well, any slower start and I would have thought this movie was about Amish Space Farmers...

This movie was pretty bad. The writing was bad. The editing was bad. The movie felt like they just threw a bunch of scenes together in the hopes that the audience would just follow along like "oh, sure". 
It's a shame because I really liked the idea of it. People can compare it to whatever franchise they want to, as it pulled from many. But this was just a bad film. I was rolling my eyes at dialogue, confused about characters motivations and got bored with the ridiculous amount of "let's just make this scene look cool rather than putting any creative work into it". 
Won't watch again and won't recommend anyone else to do so.

Rebel Moon Part 1 A Child Of Fire Is a combination of sci-fi and fantasy with a breathtaking musical score filled with hope, power & creativity at its core. The mission of the rebel force is laid out at the beginning & each character is unique and engaging with their own capabilities and motivations meshing together as one as they collide in an epic battle lifestyle. There are also plenty of twists & turns throughout the movie to keep one at the edge of their seats! The full movie experience is in two parts, the second movie to come out April 19th, 2024. This 'part one' is an excellent introduction to a new sci-fi fantasy adventure!
Felt like a live action FinalFantasy. Liked it a lot.

This is so bad that theories of AI writing exist.  The language is pompous and non-communicative.  Large exposition dumps are interrupted by comic-book speech bubbles that propel the plot from action scene to action scene, which alone is a break from utter boredom.  The actors are top notch, the CGI is good for a streaming movie, the story has been lifted from the Seven Samurai which was reworked as the Magnificent Seven, but to no avail.  Both those films created tension and an interest in the Ronin or gun-fighters.  Not so here, where their cardboard nature is as real as the blue screen the actors stand in front of.  It completely lacks substance.

What a intriguing new universe to explore. Character builds are fresh and exciting, so much to look forward too durring the second viewing. This is Gobots trying to be Starwars

I was so excited to see what the end of all star wars was going to be...seeing that Star Wars is my all time favorite franchises. That being said, I can understand why George Lucas rejected this. I don't know what was worse, the gratuitous "hero" shots all over the movie, felt like Zach stroking his own ego at every corner, or the horrible dialog and acting. I can't blame the actors for that, I blame the director for giving them the wrong direction. The music was unnecessarily "epic" on every kinda hero shot moment. It was queue the hero music..she's going to sneeze...!! So, Star Wars franchise killer I think not...lol BTW this was my very first ever movie review. How did I do? ;P

This was hands down one of the worst movies i've ever seen. Not only was it derivative but it was borderline plagiarism of some of the most beloved Sci-Fi classics as well as some other beloved media such as the Magnificent Seven. The movie boasts good visuals, and thats where the positives end. It is pretentious, poorly written and even worse acted. Even it being in the Star Wars universe (as it was originally intended) would not have saved this slop from being a blatant creatively bankrupt laughingstock of the sci-fi fantasy "space opera" genre. Please for the love of god, if this movie interests you, go watch Dune part 1 instead, as it boasts similar visuals without the brain rot attached.

First off, I'm going to start by saying when professional critics rate a movie bad, majority of the time I can almost guarantee I will like it.

A collection of pretty schlock. The film lacks any depth of character or the slightest homage to the hero's quest. There are better written video game stories, otherwise I would say it might work as video game. The two most sympathetic and interesting characters were left in the first act (a water girl and a droid - both would have made better protagonists than the shallow archetypes in the story). It could have been better with even an amateur writer at the helm. Story first, not spectacle. Disappointing.

Rebel Moon part 1 is damned Amazing!!! Akira Kurosawa would be proud‚Ä¶. Hint. So first off I am old enough to have seen the first Star Wars Commercial trailer on a 1977 Panasonic TV.. and then see the movie 12 times in a row in Waikiki in 1977‚Ä¶ since then I spent 30 years in the Marines fighting 2 actual Wars‚Ä¶ been to every Con and still ticking‚Ä¶ the negative reviewers can go swallow a light saber‚Ä¶ Blind. 
The story line in Rebel Moon and the characters are all familiar going back to decades of other parables‚Ä¶. (hello Tron and last Avatar) is a believable sleeper bad ass chic ala Vazquez in Aliens‚Ä¶ Gen Titus in a Gladiator stadium wanting to Die with Honor!!!???

Soooo let's start one they aren't space Nazis they are just Nazis in space. The CGI starts out great first world looks awesome. But in my opinion the visuals fade very quickly after leaving. The ssssssssssssssslllllllooooooooooowwwwwwwwwww mmmmmmmooooooooo is everywhere they are farming in slow mo. Slow mo doesn't make things more important or better. Now my second huge gripe is the constant fucking exposition dumps Jesus they are nearly constant 1-2 in every arc. You can show or tell ZS does both bold move but you can't do it 9 times. Now great plot idea to build a team but for me the team is too big smaller team would help us care more about the charters so when things happen we can really feel the outcomes. Also let's talk about the leading lady looks great but I have trouble really connecting to her she feels very forced and I think maybe the directors cut can bridge this gap but why release it. The visuals are great I suggest watching it in theaters or make it as cinematic as possible. Think felt more like a what you missed catch up to a tv series very episodic continuity was an issue for me. Which brings me to pacing which wasn't very good. Maybe the directors cut can save it and really make it resonate with me for now I want to give it a 5.7/10 for the fact it's a new IP for ZS I will say a 6.2/10

Rebel Moon is so desperate to be epic that it constantly trips itself up by not giving you a reason to care. Monologues with drama club level dialogue are thrown around without giving you a single reason to care about the characters. It's a masterclass in the worst kind of story telling which is "a thing happens, then another thing happens, then another thing happens" and all the while I just don't care about any of it because I haven't been given a reason to. Some of the actions scenes are decent but slow-mo is overused. CGI is decent but uninspired. If you have anything else to watch give it a go before you watch this absolute clunker.

I really enjoyed this. I was grabbed straight away by the fantasy elements thrown into a sci fi world. As a fan of Zack Snyders normally, and a fan of sci fi, and fantasy, it just came together with a fantastic combination of things I enjoy. 

I understand some of the "these characters needed more development" criticism; a lot went on and some of them in particular, their motivations were unclear, things that I'm sure the longer cut later will clear up but issues none the less. It didn't hinder my enjoyment, just some I'd have liked to see more of. 

The world building was really great and seeing this play out as the first half of a larger story; giving a little context and purposefully leaving out some elements that are due to play forward next film was interesting.

While it could have served from developing some of the characters stronger, I loved the world we saw and am so excited to see it all expand

A movie for fiction lovers.
Those who don't like fiction in its purest essence will say that they didn't like it, that they thought it was so-so, among other lame reasons. If you're reading this, don't draw conclusions from these poor people. The movie is excellent in every respect, with excellent special effects, an interesting story about an overwhelming and savage force over people incapable of defending themselves and which will have much more to come in part 2, excellent setting, among others. For lovers of star wars, star trek, lord of the rings and fans of themes involving authoritarianism, you'll give this movie a 10, for those who love fiction, you'll give it something close to that. The movie is excellent and I recommend you draw your own conclusions from it.

Due to the audacious marketing that this was the NEXT Star Wars, It was automatically held up on a high pedestal. That's something that you need to allow your audience to proclaim, not your lackey marketing goblins. It took me awhile to separate myself from that and just look at it as it was. 

It was fine. It was certainly visual and it had some genre panache. At times, it felt like they threw every successful scifi franchise in an AI blender and said cook. The characters were interesting enough. I just hardly know much about any of them outside of Kora. There wasn't much character development. Sure, each of this Sci- fi fellowship can handle their own but that's not who they are to their core. When big things start happening in the story, I just shrugged. They are still strangers to me and the danger is very low stakes. All very frustrating as we have the capacity for deep story telling with the glimmer of mythology from the Princess Issa story. That's basically as deep as it gets. 

The third act definitely felt rushed and very sudden. Not in a fun a-ha, gotcha, way. Kinda like they were assessing that they needed to end and decided to end. By doing so, they put in a beat where they killed the weight of some of the important setup by the narrator at the beginning. Jist cast it aside with no consequences. Overall making the payoff a bit hollow. 

Here's hoping Pt. 2 paves the way more thoughtfully.

Rebel Moon Part One was a bit of a letdown for me. I had heard that this was originally a pitch for a Star Wars movie, but I went in with certain expectations. I was imagining a slightly grittier version of Star Wars, and instead, it was a mashup of stereotypical Sci-Fi tropes and far too much slow-motion action. 

The theming of the movie was all over the place as well. It appeared that they were trying to go with a sort of Roman-inspired theming for the main antagonists, however, it was done in a way that felt very much like several other large Sci-Fi franchises. There were also themes of Westerns and samurai/ninja theming in there as well and they didn't find a way to blend them successfully in my opinion. On the same planet, there was also a village that was of a northern European style akin to Viking culture, and they rode their animals a day ride to a town and it was essentially a futuristic mashup of a Wild West town. No two places seemed to be connected in this universe with everything having such vastly different design languages.

Aside from the failed theming of the film, I had some serious issues with pacing as well. When the protagonists were traveling, there was no time between their previous encounters and the new. They would be on the ground about to leave and then immediately in another area about to meet with the person they were looking for. There was no buildup in meeting any of the individuals they were looking for, and there was no real reason that they were making any of the stops in the first place. It wasn't revealed until nearly the end of the film why they had been picking up particular individuals, and the 'twist' in the story was seen for a long time coming. Again with the timing being so odd, nearly all of the action in this is of the Slow-Motion variety. While I don't have anything against that in itself, when you watch the same people moving very slowly for about 5 minutes in what could have been a 30-second encounter, you start to get a bit bored.

I also have some issues with the story itself, however I won't spoil that here. I'll just say that the only characters that I was truly invested in either died after being on screen for a few minutes or had a very minor role in the film. I wasn't able to find a good connection to any of the main cast as all of their characters were truly unlikable except for the farmer. Every other main character had some element to them that made them feel as though they could be disposable and that I wouldn't mind if they died in the film.

The story of Rebel Moon was a bit too much thrown in your face. The audience wasn't allowed to 'see' the story unfold as there was far too much of the story that was 'told'. A common theme in great films is to make the story 'seen, not told.' Rebel Moon failed miserably at that. 

One area that this film shines through is its effects. I thought that they looked quite good. There is a robot character that shows up quite early in the film, and it looks fantastic. It's not all good though, as many of the aliens in the film look like they took a person and altered them slightly. None of them apart from one in my opinion look rather good. They seem to be just costumed people with rubber faces. There were no unique alien ideas, again aside from one that used another person to talk for them.

Overall, if you are interested in cheesy Sci-Fi and don't mind a half-baked story then go ahead and watch this. If however you don't like the over-troped Sci-Fi and slow-motion messes, stay away it's not for you.

Generally I was Entertained and plan to watch Part 2 but there some parts that did not feel right. For example some dialogues felt a bit weird also it might would have helped starting this first part with a smaller main cast to flesh out characters a bit more.

Story is muddled and is just the same old David vs Goliath trope that has been done to death especially in these space "opera's". All hype and zero substance. If it was a Star Wars saga you'd buy in for the nostalgia and familiarity but, on its own, offers little to nothing to make you want to go back for more. If your short on time just watch the previews, you get the entire story and the best bits of the action, literally. I'll still watch part 2, probably, for some closure and hope of redemption. However, it doesnt even end with a cliffhanger or hook to entice you back. Bitterly dissapointed because I wanted it to be as good as the promo team made it out to be.

Completely raw thoughts as I watch. Premise is 7 Samurai + Dune / Star Wars. The village and villagers are as naive and ignorant as the ones in 7 Samurai. The Motherworld army / space nazis (actually more like space soviets) are ruthless as the Empire's / First Order's troopers. Replace the protagonists of Star Wars with 7 Samurai, replace 1/2 the plot of Star Wars with 7 Samurai (Instead of a death star and farm boy becoming a jedi, it's farmers and "outcasts" vs space warmongers. Ngl i also see some references to like Clash of the Titans, when Tarak (Tarzan duh; side note: dude looks like he could pull off as Tarzan) was riding the bennu similary to how Perseus was riding Pegasus. Dunno why this movie also gives me Warhammer vibes; probably the outfits and weapons. Also gives me Bungie games vibes, especially D2; from how some of the lore is presented, some of the cg scenes (kinda feels like game cutscenes or sortta like cg from Tron; but that's fair enough considering tech advances and budget), some of the movements and skills. Tbh I'm fine with slo-mo scenes in films, I feel like there were some moments where it's unecessary or a little too much. Love the twist with Kai (side note: rewatch 7 samurai if there was ever a betrayal like this). Last battle between Kora and Noble reminds me of Rogue One. The scene when all 6 of them were side-by-side was for sure a call back to ZSJL / JL ending where the 6 were together. Noble definitly got Darth Vader treatment at the end (2nd chance at life by his master) can't wait to see the threat he'll become next. Scoring is great overall. For context 7 samurai was like 3 and 1/2 hours long so this film would ofc feel incomplete without it's part 2 since the premise is pretty much 7 samurai. Overall, i'd say it was a good film. If the cut / R+ version is better when it releases I'll revisit scoring.

Rebel Moon is a terrible movie that copies from better movies and ruins them. The movie is full of Star Wars references, but they are lame and boring. It is about a girl who fights an evil empire with a laser sword, a half-vampire prince who is a rip-off of Blade, a spider queen who is a match up of Queen of the Damned and Charlotte's Web, a Nazi who is a rip-off of Schindler's List, and a robot who is a rip-off of Bicentennial Man. Not to mention the highlight was the action sequence from a rip-off Mulan meets Asajj Ventress. It  is also full of starships that look weird rip-off MCU. The movie's aesthetics and sounds are also rip-off of Dune, but they are dull and annoying. Wish I can have those 2hrs back.

Feels like a bad star wars film. This could've been so good... but it's not. I want to love the characters, but there's no depth provided. There's also CG moments that take you out of it. They probably should've broken this into more parts so they had more time to develop the characters.

The visuals were mostly on the amazing side (with some really bad CGI thrown in at random and lens flare for some reason) but dear lord, the plot and characters were terrible. The dialogue was just flat and unmotivated. It read like a DnD group starting an adventure without actually role-playing their character's motivations for joining. No one really resisted joining. 

There was no real connection with the side characters. We never really saw too much of their living situations or even personality from any of them so I felt no connection to anyone involved. The music was telling me to feel awed by a line delivery or a speech but the audience has no real reason to care.  It was disappointing to be TOLD things and not shown them. You want to tell me the general is a tactical genius? Okay, but he didn't do any thing to warrant that description.  Exposition dump on Kora's back-story? You tell me she's a badass and her flashbacks sometimes reflect that but she has stormtrooper aim. 

Also, we were shown the dreadnaught can fire bomb a planet from orbit. It seems supremely silly for farmers to fight it. Maybe they should have been looking for a whole fleet of pirates to take on the warhammer 40k ship.

I felt genuinely bad for Tarak though. No one thought to give him a shirt all movie. He went from desert planet to the cold of space. No shirt.

Zack Snider is like a music video director and I will explain.

He is not in the service of the story. What he does, is try to create "cinematic moments but,,, he can't "mix" his attempts at continus "cinematic moments" in the editing room as none of them match each other in tones, colors or ambiences.
It worked great in "300" as he only had 1 storyline to tell, but as soon as you add a second one,, it becomes harder.    

 

If you watch a K-pop or rap music video and you have people dancing to it, most of the time, these people can't dance pretty well so, they make cuts (like in a fight scene where people can't really fight) to present them in their best light and here is where it bogs down.

The lighting for all these scenes, never has any continuity as the scene's lighting is reset to re-give the best light for the next cut of that scene. There is no shadow game to emphasize the story telling and what you are getting is a "picture" that moves instead of a scene.
If you look carefully at the different angles of camera happening in the same scene, you will notice that the shadows are not in the same place on the actors and the sets behind them as the scene goes on.  

Now, if you take that "Moving picture" and use a volume screen, green screen or CGI,, the lighting (that is already not working) is really not working in the completed scene as the entire lighting isn't matching and that give you that feeling of coldness which is now the trademark of Snider. 

 

That blue or red/orange hue that he is known for, isn't a signature skill. It's what happens when you desaturate, reduce exposure and crank the contrast up in your video editing software to hide imperfections in your footage.

Speaking of color grading in this movie, it's all over the place. You will notice that we jump from an orange hue in one scene, to a blue hue, then to a classic cinematic hue in an other without any reasons for it. 
In movie making, the use of these hues are there to emphasize the mood of a scene or a story line. It could be also used to differentiate locations but,,,,,, in this movie, the changes are done for no apparent reasons and sometimes in the same fucking scene. 

This is why besides the script and the acting, this movie is unwatchable. There is no redeeming qualities to it.

If you take other Snider movies, they all had redeeming quality. 
In 300, the script was garbage but the visuals saved the movie (Cinematic moments)
In Man of Steel, the script wasn't great but the visuals (until the final fight scene) saved the movie plus, it's fucking Superman. (Cinematic moments)
In the Watchmen, the script saved the movie as the acting was atrocious. 

Not in this movie. Nothing can save it.

Rebel Moon Part 1 has taken the world of storytelling to unprecedented heights. Brace yourself for an unforgettable experience, crafted with an unimaginably incredible storyline and breathtaking visuals that will leave you at the edge of your seat.

The first thing that strikes you about Rebel Moon is its mind-blowing plot. This captivating tale transcends the boundaries of traditional storytelling, expertly blending together elements of science fiction, adventure, and intrigue that seamlessly draw you in from the very first scene. The depth of the characters, their development, and the intricate web of relationships they navigate are nothing short of enchanting.

Throughout this thrilling narrative, Rebel Moon introduces us to a richly detailed world, which successfully transports us to a reality painted with visual genius. The visual effects in this film are next-level stunning, leaving the viewers spellbound. From the awe-inspiring landscapes to the meticulously crafted spaceships and futuristic technologies, each frame is a visual feast for the eyes, leaving us in awe of the sheer beauty and creativity on display.

The exceptional cinematography and attention to detail further enhance the storytelling experience. The brilliant use of varying camera angles and perfect lighting helps to create a sense of intensity and suspense, allowing us to uncover hidden aspects of the story with each passing moment. It truly feels as if we are right there, immersed in every twist and turn of Rebel Moon's epic adventure.

Moreover, the exceptional performances of the cast bring the story to life in an unforgettable way. The actors' dedication and skill captivate the audience, as their talents give birth to multi-dimensional characters that we can't help but cheer for or empathize with. Their chemistry and the emotional connections they convey further elevate the impact of the already-compelling narrative.

Rebel Moon Part 1 is a rare gem that defies expectations and redefines the boundaries of modern storytelling. It showcases the magic that can be achieved when a remarkable story plot meets breathtaking visuals and stellar performances. This film is a true celebration of artistic brilliance and innovation, setting new standards in the world of cinema.

Prepare yourself for an unparalleled journey that will leave you craving for more. Rebel Moon Part 1 is an absolute must-watch that will undoubtedly leave a lasting mark on both casual viewers and avid fans of science fiction. Don't hesitate to immerse yourself in this astounding adventure.
It's a beatiful movie , i love this moon

I don't get the hate, this movie was awesome! Rich lore, great lead, stunning visuals, and a truly menacing villain. The complaints about it being a Star Wars ripoff are overblown, however the movie makes no secret of its influences and wears them proudly on its  sleeve. Can't wait for part two!
Restored my faith in sci fi. Gravity over irony, great actors, classic tale, nothing cutesy just 100% enthralling adventure. Expected to hate, shocked to totally love.

I loved how the characters were introduced. Removed all the fluff. Took me on a love/hate rollercoaster. I will spend my money on this franchise. Give me more as soon as possible. Thank you.

"Should we spend more time on storyline and dialogue?"

"Nah, pretty sure pointless action will do as long as we make it look cool. The dialogue can be super contrived with a plot that is meh."

"Should we a least make the action scenes somewhat believable within the sci-fi realm of our own creation?"

"Nah."

"So we basically assume the audience is super dumb and won't care?"

"Exactly."

Visually stunning, mild story pacing issues but overall made me feel like I was watching Warhammer 40K Star Wars and that was fine. All of the tech and species of aliens and cultures definitely have me hoping there's an extended universe or franchise that comes.

They slow mo'd the slow mo. This was just bad. As a sci fi fanatic I wanted to enjoy this film oh so much. It was an immediate disappointment. It was then hilarious to make fun of until well, it wasn't.

Rebel Moon cuts a critical path through an immense, lived-in universe with history and drops plenty of inside references to events, people, and places just beyond our current horizons to tantalize viewers for the future, all while delivering a cohesive narrative that is incredibly fun to watch.

Overall I enjoyed it.  It's rare we get new IP's in general let alone a new space epic with hints of Dune and Warhammer 40k as inspiration.  The only thing I wish was improved is character development.  We really don't have a good idea of who the "heroes" are.  I honestly didn't even know most of their names until the end of the film.  Looks like more character insights will come in part 2 based off the trailer.  Looking forward to it.

This movie is old school fun meets new school technology.  Don't listen to the critics. It's clearly a "part one" which should excite viewers for the second part rather than feel it is far too open-ended as some reviews suggest. The story is not the best ever written‚Ä¶ but let's not pretend some of our favorite cultural films have been the best of the best. Rebel Moon is worth your time.

What in the world did I just watch? This movie is soulless, cold, and utterly shallow. Am I supposed to care about any of these characters? The pacing is a mess, there's almost no meaningful character development, and the visual effects look very cheap and unfinished. I've played video games with more realistic visual effects. This movie is so obviously a cheap knock off. It's no wonder Disney passed on this.
Critics are crazy! That movie was awesome! Style to spare, cool characters, incredible effects and design. Just flat out cool!

I loved this movie!  While many people are complaining and calling this a Star Wars rip off, I would have to disagree. I loved all the nods to other films and the little snippets here and there from other films such as Star Wars, Dune, Harry Potter and probably so many more. I honestly look forward to watching it again and seeing what other pieces have been so obviously loved by the writers that they put these things into this film. They have taken things that have been done before just like any other writer and film maker and spun it into something of their own while creating something new and mesmerizing. I would of liked to of seen a little more characterization and build up to the extra characters that were being recruited in the film, as I dont feel much level of attachment to them. I felt more attachment to the spider lady with her little speech about the mines and what has been done to her. I felt more
 for her than a recruited good guy. But overall I really liked this Film. A little bit of the cgi looked goofy in a few spots ,particularly a flying animal scene. But I can overlook that. I am very happy to see more SciFI/ Fantasy being made. I look forward to the next installment.

The movie is an absolute blast. There is so much world-building, with a visual feast. I am excited to see where this story leads.

I was lucky to catch a preview screening. I expected to see a copy of Star Wars. But what I saw wasn't Star Wars. It was much bigger. The director created a living world from scratch. We feel its enormity, we meet a multitude of characters, each of whom has their own story and role in this galaxy. This is no longer the sterile and colorful sci-fi that Disney gives us, but a full-fledged cosmic dark fantasy. A production that exceeds the expectations of modern audiences and gives something more.
Visually, musically, acted, narratively... In every respect, Rebel Moon shines and I have no doubt that for many of you it will be the best production of this year, if not the decade. This film simply must be watched.
Maybe during the first viewing you will be a bit overwhelmed by the pace at which the story is presented, but during the second viewing, when you know what this production is about, you will appreciate this film even more. Really, watch this before someone will spoil you this masterpiece ;)

Zach Snyder's Star Wars, (coughs) I mean Rebel Moon, this is a good sci-fi film, it's got elements of genre blending, elements of a Viking/ Norse epic, a Western, Seven Samurai, the Magnificent Seven, and Zacks version of Star Wars. This isn't the same thing as Star Wars it has a different vibe. It is a quality Sci-fi film with a good mature story, it has an epic score. Two times I could picture Darth Vader coming into the next scene based upon the audio design. The visuals are great. The story is great. I took a road trip to the Bay Theater to see this in theaters and I'm glad I did. I really liked it. I want to see the R rated version. It feels like some important elements of the story could be expanded upon. There are hints that a sex scene may have been cut. Overall, I like the tone, the visual style and the audio design. I wish it was available in a larger theater. The small theater / screen didn't show it in the size and scale I would have preferred to see. This needs to be shown on the larger screens to a mass audience. This is a solid franchise starter. It's a quality movie. I wish it was available in more theaters and on larger screens as it deserves. This should have been a wider release. I am glad I took the road trip to see it in theaters. I can wait to see the full R rated version of the film.

But even the family friendly version has several mature themes in it than the run of the mill marvel movie for example, it respects what it is and doesn't hold back.

Rebel Moon a story that tells a tale of a former soldier known as kora that ran off from tyrannical empire to live peacefully at a small moon called veldt until admiral atticus noble lands on the planet and the quest to find rebels that willing to join them to save the whole universe.

What do i think of rebel moon ? 

The film itself ranging from visuals spectacle to its world building it was phenomenal. Zack knows what he's doing from the ground up personally for me it's already ten times better than star wars content for the past 20 years. This should be watch on the biggest screen and on imax for sure how good the visuals is. And for the story and characters all set well and done. Every character is a definite show stealer especially Kora and Kai both of them are badassess. The side characters also did and serve their purpose to the story while i have small gripes i would say that the story should be more fleshed out and they could just add up around 20 minutes more to the film so that it can breathe and seen more characters clild shine throughout. 

All and all Rebel moon is by far one of the best action films in 2023. Don't forget to check it out.
